revisions:
[{'created': '2011-12-14 16:32:30.000000000', 'message': "Introduces UID's & domain models (bp portable-identifiers)

This is an initial redesign of a series where we're moving
away from the existing keystone backend/model architecture
towards a simpler design more in line with other OpenStack
projects.

- Implemented User & Tenant UID's
  - Migrations to introduce users.uid and tenants.uid
  - Migrations populate these columns with existing PK ID's
  - Populating them with UUID's moving forward
- Domain models
  - Allows us to keep backend models in the backend,
    and use business objects in keystone.logic
  - Starts to simplify de/serialization
- Added 'database' commands to keystone-manage
  - e.g. ./bin/keystone-manage database [sync|version|version_contro|upgrade|downgrade]
- Improved test coverage
  - Add database migration tests
  - Cleaner handling of migration errors
  - New attribute is commented out in sqlalchemy model (for illustration)
- Refactored service.py to be class-based (IdentityService)
  - Retains configuration in self.options on init
  - Added __init__ which inits ClassManagers
  - Moved backend initialization to IdentityService

Change-Id: I4ac00c190968b24640d25806f45b33c7aa2c5c92

commit_message:
Introduces UID's & domain models (bp portable-identifiers)

This is an initial redesign of a series where we're moving
away from the existing keystone backend/model architecture
towards a simpler design more in line with other OpenStack
projects.

- Implemented User & Tenant UID's
  - Migrations to introduce users.uid and tenants.uid
  - Migrations populate these columns with existing PK ID's
  - Populating them with UUID's moving forward
- Domain models
  - Allows us to keep backend models in the backend,
    and use business objects in keystone.logic
  - Starts to simplify de/serialization
- Added 'database' commands to keystone-manage
  - e.g. ./bin/keystone-manage database [sync|version|version_contro|upgrade|downgrade]
- Improved test coverage
  - Add database migration tests
  - Cleaner handling of migration errors
  - New attribute is commented out in sqlalchemy model (for illustration)
- Refactored service.py to be class-based (IdentityService)
  - Retains configuration in self.options on init
  - Added __init__ which inits ClassManagers
  - Moved backend initialization to IdentityService
- Pylint updates
  - added many @staticmethods where recommended
  - turned off checks where appropriate (or to be fixed)

Change-Id: I4ac00c190968b24640d25806f45b33c7aa2c5c92

subject: Adds runing_deleted_instance reaper task.
messages:
[{'account_id': 475, 'date': '2011-12-07 08:47:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Excuse the diff, I need to figure out dependent branches so I can hook this up to the periodic-task-to-decorator refactor and the fix-context-read-deleted patch.'}, {'account_id': 1801, 'date': '2011-12-07 17:33:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

No review yet, but I was wondering if this addresses the need described in this blueprint:
  https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/database-reaper'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2011-12-07 17:54:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Looking at the blueprint, this is a bit different.

The case we're trying to solve for here is when the database reports an instance as 'deleted' but for various unknown reasons, the instance is still running on the host machine.

We'd really like to figure out the root cause of this, however, since the issue is effecting our performance testing, we're attempting to work around it for now by just reaping (shutting down and destroying) these erroneously running instances."}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2011-12-15 02:09:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

Abandoning in favor in https://review.openstack.org/#change,2348'}]

commit_message:
Rename 'options' variables to 'conf'

In the common-config patch, I'm going to be using 'conf' as the name of
the variable holding configuration values rather than 'options.

This patch does the renaming across the codebase without making any
functional changes.

Change-Id: I3a86fc01fc76825d6d1e86af882eb8245828ce5f

Once the asserts are fixed to be 2.6-friendly, I'll +1 again :-)"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2011-12-08 22:38:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2011-12-08 22:40:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

commit_message:
Add new cfg module

As discussed on the mailing list and described here:

  http://wiki.openstack.org/CommonConfigModule

The module implements an API for defining configuration options and
reading values for those options that a user may have set in a config
file or on the command line.

The module will be part of openstack-common and glance will consume
it from there once openstack-common makes a release with an API
compatibility commitment.

Change-Id: Ideedf77e5e16fa4e6ca742cfb49f5539c5a4a746

revisions:
[{'created': '2011-12-07 13:53:25.000000000', 'message': "Convert glance to use the new cfg module

The changes here are substantial and widespread, but in summary:

  - We use cfg to parse the CLI and config files, rather than optparse
    and PasteDeploy

  - A schema is defined for all configuration options close to the code
    which uses the option

  - 2 ConfigOpts sub-classes are added to config.py basically just
    defining how to find config files; this means we can now use e.g.
    glance.conf for base config values which glance-api.conf can
    override

  - load_paste_app() is changed to load the paste app from the last
    config file in the stack and pass the app the ConfigOpts instance

  - The generic app and filter factories in wsgi.py are modified to
    pass a ConfigOpts instance to the apps and filters

  - A ConfigOpts subclass is added for the unit tests which writes out
    config values to a temporary config file and uses cfg to parse that

I've tried to keep the switch as unobtrusive as possible leaving further
cleanups for later e.g.

  - Moving PasteDeploy config out of the config files - I think it would
    be good to aim for having users modify the PasteDeploy config files
    only in fairly rare circumstances. To achieve this, we might define
    a number of common pipelines in the PasteDeploy config and allow
    the user to choose between those pipelines in the glance config.

  - We should add help strings to all the opts, even just for the sake
    of documenting them

  - We should move a bunch of the options into groups - e.g. all the
    rabbit options

  - We no longer rely on config files for default values, so the default
    config files could contain nothing but comments - i.e. explaining
    each option and showing what the default for it is - making it
    obvious where a user has explicitly set a value

There are a couple of behavioural changes which I don't think are
signifcant but are worth mentioning:

  - We used to support passing a config file as a positional argument
    but don't anymore; AFAICT, it was only used by glance-manage when
    launching servers and I've changed that to pass --config-file

  - log_opt_values() doesn't log unknown opts, so won't log any values
    for opts which get registered at runtime later

Change-Id: Iafa998a2a8d860f1ad57e2cd2afee69686ed58ba
"}, {'created': '2011-12-08 22:38:48.000000000', 'message': "Convert glance to use the new cfg module

commit_message:
Convert glance to use the new cfg module

The changes here are substantial and widespread, but in summary:

  - We use cfg to parse the CLI and config files, rather than optparse
    and PasteDeploy

  - A schema is defined for all configuration options close to the code
    which uses the option

  - 2 ConfigOpts sub-classes are added to config.py basically just
    defining how to find config files; this means we can now use e.g.
    glance.conf for base config values which glance-api.conf can
    override

  - load_paste_app() is changed to load the paste app from the last
    config file in the stack and pass the app the ConfigOpts instance

  - The generic app and filter factories in wsgi.py are modified to
    pass a ConfigOpts instance to the apps and filters

  - A ConfigOpts subclass is added for the unit tests which writes out
    config values to a temporary config file and uses cfg to parse that

I've tried to keep the switch as unobtrusive as possible leaving further
cleanups for later e.g.

  - Moving PasteDeploy config out of the config files - I think it would
    be good to aim for having users modify the PasteDeploy config files
    only in fairly rare circumstances. To achieve this, we might define
    a number of common pipelines in the PasteDeploy config and allow
    the user to choose between those pipelines in the glance config.

  - We should add help strings to all the opts, even just for the sake
    of documenting them

  - We should move a bunch of the options into groups - e.g. all the
    rabbit options

  - We no longer rely on config files for default values, so the default
    config files could contain nothing but comments - i.e. explaining
    each option and showing what the default for it is - making it
    obvious where a user has explicitly set a value

There are a couple of behavioural changes which I don't think are
signifcant but are worth mentioning:

  - We used to support passing a config file as a positional argument
    but don't anymore; AFAICT, it was only used by glance-manage when
    launching servers and I've changed that to pass --config-file

  - log_opt_values() doesn't log unknown opts, so won't log any values
    for opts which get registered at runtime later

Change-Id: Iafa998a2a8d860f1ad57e2cd2afee69686ed58ba

Mitchell', 'email': 'klmitch@mit.edu', 'username': 'klmitch'}, {'_account_id': 1132, 'name': 'Brian Waldon', 'email': 'brian@waldon.cc', 'username': 'bcwaldon'}, {'_account_id': 1247, 'name': 'Mark McLoughlin', 'email': 'markmc@redhat.com', 'username': 'markmc'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 7, 'date': '2011-12-08 23:12:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Rock on, Mark! Nice work :)

My only concern is for existing installations. These changes will make their existing conf files dead on arrival.

To prevent this, we will need to create a corresponding packaging merge proposal that patches the glance-*.conf files in the same way as was done here:

https://code.launchpad.net/~jaypipes/glance/ubuntu/+merge/82318

So, good to go, but need a packaging changeset, too :)

-jay"}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2011-12-08 23:15:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Looks OK to me, but I am not sure I understand why we need to do this; can't we instead extend paste in some fashion such that the paste.app_factory and paste.filter_factory end up being implicit?  IIRC, that's how nova does this..."}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2011-12-08 23:18:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Nova uses @classmethods in its various WSGI objects for factory methods...'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2011-12-09 07:16:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thanks Jay and Kevin

Jay - I've never touched Debian/Ubuntu packaging in my life and I really don't see why I should start now for this patch :)

Unless maybe, we're going to have folks update the Fedora packaging too when they change stuff? :)"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2011-12-09 07:17:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Also, Kevin - in the patch to move to cfg, you'll see why I really needed generic factories"}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2011-12-09 17:06:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Mark, yes, I'm aware that you don't do Ubuntu/Debian packaging ;)

However, if someone updates Glance after installing on Ubuntu/Debian, this patch will cause their servers to fail to boot... Is that something we want to encourage?

At the very minimum, the following should be done:

* Jay to make debian patch for upgrading the paste deploy files
* Mark to make Fedora-related packaging changes (I assume similar problems would occur for existing Fedora installations
* Jay to work with Jesse to get corresponding devstack updates made (as all devstack installations will also break immediately with this patch)
* Jay to work with Dan Prince to update the chef cookbooks

Until the above is done, I'm afraid I'm not keen on pushing this through. I hope you understand.
-jay"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2011-12-11 10:59:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Basically, I don't think its upstream's job to anticipate all possible downstream packaging changes and have those changes lined up before making a change upstream

Maybe that works while you've only got e.g. Ubuntu packaging and CI to worry about, but as you gain more and more downstreams it stops being feasible

As a downstream packager, I'm well used to reacting to upstream changes after they happened

Also, I think this shows why the PasteDeploy config should be separated from the main glance config file - IMHO, users should only need to modify the PasteDeploy config itself in very unusual cases"}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2011-12-12 14:50:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: No score

Mark, I totally agree about separating paste pipelines from regular configuration stuff. There's been a bug open about that for a long time:

https://bugs.launchpad.net/glance/+bug/815208

Look, I really like this work and it seems I might be the only old fuddy-duddy bringing up concerns about upgrades :)

If you can get bcwaldon, sirp, or other Glance contribs to second Vek's +1, I'll approve it.

-jay"}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2011-12-12 19:58:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

I'm not as concerned with having anticipatory packaging updates as Jay is, so I'm going to +1 this. I do agree that we shouldn't be making the job of the packagers more difficult, and as long as we're up-front about the changes we're making, I think we should be able to move on. I just don't think its feasible to update *everything* downstream. I wouldn't be against defining a checklist for these kinds of changes (similar to what Jay mentioned above  withopenstack-chef, devstack, ubuntu, redhat, etc) that helps us ensure the right communication is happening."}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2011-12-14 21:02:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2011-12-14 21:05:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/glance/89384/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/glance-pep8/387/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/glance-merge/214/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2011-12-14 21:05:27.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2011-12-07 12:43:17.000000000', 'message': 'Add generic PasteDeploy app and filter factories

These generic factories allow us to dump the copied and pasted
app_factory and filter_factory methods in the codebase.

The main difference is the paste configuration changes from:

  [app:apiv1app]
  paste.app_factory = glance.api.v1:app_factory
  ...
  [filter:cache]
  paste.filter_factory = glance.api.middleware.cache:filter_factory

to this:

  [app:apiv1app]
  paste.app_factory = glance.common.wsgi:app_factory
  glance.app_factory = glance.api.v1:API
  ...
  [filter:cache]
  paste.filter_factory = glance.common.wsgi:filter_factory
  glance.filter_factory = glance.api.middleware.cache:CacheFilter

Apart from reducing code duplication, this will also allow us to have
the generic factories inject other data into the apps and filters.

Change-Id: I1d2be5630ab61d29b8948ff88d58e6e1b11c2e5f
'}]
commit_message:
Add generic PasteDeploy app and filter factories

These generic factories allow us to dump the copied and pasted
app_factory and filter_factory methods in the codebase.

The main difference is the paste configuration changes from:

  [app:apiv1app]
  paste.app_factory = glance.api.v1:app_factory
  ...
  [filter:cache]
  paste.filter_factory = glance.api.middleware.cache:filter_factory

to this:

  [app:apiv1app]
  paste.app_factory = glance.common.wsgi:app_factory
  glance.app_factory = glance.api.v1:API
  ...
  [filter:cache]
  paste.filter_factory = glance.common.wsgi:filter_factory
  glance.filter_factory = glance.api.middleware.cache:CacheFilter

Apart from reducing code duplication, this will also allow us to have
the generic factories inject other data into the apps and filters.

Change-Id: I1d2be5630ab61d29b8948ff88d58e6e1b11c2e5f

was not clear whether the user was responsible for specifying these or if

Change-Id: I32e7e7fdc9e1f3d94cb731b5b366f05cc2840d4f

was not clear whether the user was responsible for specifying these or if
this can be filled in at runtime, like %tenant_id%.

Change-Id: I32e7e7fdc9e1f3d94cb731b5b366f05cc2840d4f

commit_message:
Specify HOST_IP in endpoint template

The documentation as written uses %host_ip% for the template endpoints, but it
was not clear whether the user was responsible for specifying these or if
this can be filled in at runtime, like %tenant_id%.

I've changed the docs so host_ip is hard-coded, which is how devstack does it.

Change-Id: I32e7e7fdc9e1f3d94cb731b5b366f05cc2840d4f

commit_message:
blueprint refactor-readme-to-manual

Removes most of the content from the README to avoid it becoming outdated
and stale given that our currently maintained docs are now on
http://docs.openstack.org .  In some cases, including keystone config,
extension writing, etc. this means text from the README is being
transferred directly from the README to an external doc so we make
sure we don't lose anything.

Change-Id: Ie08db4bd4854bb45e6777b1e0abe37f51d3e5c5c

commit_message:
blueprint refactor-readme-to-manual

Removes most of the content from the README to avoid it becoming outdated
and stale given that our currently maintained docs are now on
http://docs.openstack.org .  In some cases, including keystone config,
extension writing, etc. this means text from the README is being
transferred directly from the README to an external doc so we make
sure we don't lose anything.

Change-Id: Ie08db4bd4854bb45e6777b1e0abe37f51d3e5c5c

commit_message:
Align run_tests.sh with nova.

We need for run_tests.sh to accept the same inputs and outputs from a CI
perspective. In this case, the easiest way was just to port in run_test.py.
Additionally, we need with_venv.sh to exist.

Change-Id: I25e659ed796c8a70239aab610f5b014b35443b67

Fixes a minor memory leak caused by a self-referential data structure
with a __del__() method by explicitly breaking the cycle.

(cherry picked from commit a594f4d34418c27197fe7f82eab150bc7cb70478)

Change-Id: Ic2c896d3067f8a2205abc8a43ec290fdbd92ef09
'}]
commit_message:
Fix a minor memory leak

Fixes a minor memory leak caused by a self-referential data structure
with a __del__() method by explicitly breaking the cycle.

(cherry picked from commit a594f4d34418c27197fe7f82eab150bc7cb70478)

Change-Id: Ic2c896d3067f8a2205abc8a43ec290fdbd92ef09

commit_message:
stackrc: replace ttylinux-uec images with cirros

http://launchpad.net/cirros is basically "ttylinux-uec 2.0".

These images should function wherever ttylinux-uec did, and
work well better under lxc.

Change-Id: I5b8485a7bb3518e05172b297fccd16e497463525

subject: D5 Compatibility Support
messages:
[{'account_id': 964, 'date': '2011-12-08 15:02:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

More of a question than a review. My understanding of d5 is that it requires "auth" prefixed to token requests, so would this enable either request to make it through?'}, {'account_id': 5, 'date': '2011-12-10 22:06:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Correct, Anne. Not only that, but if someone sends a request with D5 format, they are probably expecting a D5 response. So this would also make sure the response is what they are expecting...'}, {'account_id': 964, 'date': '2011-12-10 23:01:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Okay, then I'd say also modify that RST file to include a d5 JSON request example (just adds "auth:" iirc). This will help immensely as I hope to have an install/deploy guide out next week that tangentially refers to d5). Thanks!'}, {'account_id': 1475, 'date': '2011-12-13 00:44:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(1 inline comment)

See my comments on d5_compat.py.  As it is written if the auth request is not a d5 auth request then an exception gets raised and the auth request fails."}, {'account_id': 1475, 'date': '2011-12-13 18:38:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (2 inline comments)

see my additional comments in d5_compat.py'}, {'account_id': 5, 'date': '2011-12-14 13:25:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (3 inline comments)

revisions:
[{'created': '2011-12-07 08:59:11.000000000', 'message': "D5 Compatibility Support

Fixes bug 900916

Added a D5-compat front-end for Keystone which responds in
  D5 syntax if it receives a D5-formatted request.
  It also formats responses to requests that can't be identified
  as D5 or Diablo final in dual/compatible format (ugly, but works).

This is intended to be around until Essex (maybe we deprecate sooner)

Change-Id: I050d77ee3acc9d91732b5099774d82d6492ec1ca
"}, {'created': '2011-12-14 13:27:52.000000000', 'message': "D5 Compatibility Support

Fixes bug 900916

Added a D5-compat front-end for Keystone which responds in
  D5 syntax if it receives a D5-formatted request.
  It also formats responses to requests that can't be identified
  as D5 or Diablo final in dual/compatible format (ugly, but works).

This is intended to be around until Essex (maybe we deprecate sooner)

Change-Id: I050d77ee3acc9d91732b5099774d82d6492ec1ca
"}]
commit_message:
D5 Compatibility Support

Fixes bug 900916

Added a D5-compat front-end for Keystone which responds in
  D5 syntax if it receives a D5-formatted request.
  It also formats responses to requests that can't be identified
  as D5 or Diablo final in dual/compatible format (ugly, but works).

This is intended to be around until Essex (maybe we deprecate sooner)

Change-Id: I050d77ee3acc9d91732b5099774d82d6492ec1ca

commit_message:
Fix issue in test_s3_malicious_tarballs

The previous commit backported a master commit which added a test
that cannot run successfully on stable/diablo due to a missing
import.

commit_message:
Switch versioning to common Nova versioning

Use "2012.1" as the version for python-novaclient, to align with
Nova common versioning (starting with Essex-2, python-novaclient
is shipped as a Nova project deliverable. Fixes bug 904182.

Change-Id: I85d742a346bbaae1dc92a476c140f7f862a0828c

subject: Revert to using IP addresses as EC2 dnsName
messages:
[{'account_id': 1082, 'date': '2011-12-08 13:29:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I'm the one who originally moaned about this change.  It negatively affects devstack, and probably many in-house clouds (one operarted by Canonical for employees will be affected).

That said, I cannot argue strongly against them for the following reasons:
 * previously, we were returning a ip address in a field labeled 'hostname' (ec2 returns hostname)
 * the dns server that is running for openstack could be used to allow end users to resolve these names.
 * The DescribeInstances response *does* contain the ip addresses, making this really just a lack-of-client-tools issue.
 * I've submitted a merge proposal at [1] to add a '--ipv4' flag to 'euca-describe-instances' so it will show the IP address fields rather than hostnames.

--
[1] https://code.launchpad.net/~smoser/euca2ools/describe-ipv4/+merge/84881"}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2011-12-14 09:31:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2011-12-08 13:09:30.000000000', 'message': 'Revert to using IP addresses as EC2 dnsName

A recent commit introduced a change in behavior that prevents
IP addresses from being communicated to the user when using the
EC2 API. This change restores the original use of the dnsName
field while keeping the server name in privateDnsName.

Fixes bug 901594

Change-Id: Ic8c14c885a4353896814b75ac6d1c761609925ca
'}]
commit_message:
Revert to using IP addresses as EC2 dnsName

A recent commit introduced a change in behavior that prevents
IP addresses from being communicated to the user when using the
EC2 API. This change restores the original use of the dnsName
field while keeping the server name in privateDnsName.

Fixes bug 901594

Change-Id: Ic8c14c885a4353896814b75ac6d1c761609925ca

subject: Fixes Bug lp:900910
messages:
[{'account_id': 7, 'date': '2011-12-13 13:52:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

lgtm, however I wonder if passing this:

 {'createInstance': {'name': 'My Instance'}}

vs.

 {'createInstance': {'name': 'My Instance',
                     'metadata': null,
                     'personality': null, ... }}

Will cause failures?"}, {'account_id': 1073, 'date': '2011-12-13 15:53:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

per me, this should not fail as the api would translate the nulls to defaults, i.e empty dict for metadata and empty list for personality. Both of them are optional parameters.'}, {'account_id': 1073, 'date': '2011-12-13 15:54:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

it would fail if you don't pass the imageRef and flavorRef :-)"}, {'account_id': 97, 'date': '2011-12-14 03:03:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

The reasoning for the original code format was so that the optional parameters would only be included in the request if passed. With this code, all request params will always be passed (granted the non-used ones will be null), which takes away some of the control of the request. Still, I know this change was made to shorten the code. commit_message:
Remove extra swift delete_object call

This only tries to delete the manifest once when deleting an image
stored (chunked) in swift. Fixes bug 903768.

Change-Id: I65b8f3389e9965a111c4e774f4d1b6f7bbe71a9b

Bug #890028

commit_message:
Implementation of the BP services-insertion-wrapper inside the Cisco Plugin

This utility offers a simplify way to insert and remove network services
in the path of the traffic to the server VMs, by splitting the network
into two, and having the service bridge between the two networks,
in the process applying the service. This model is called In-Path
(Bump in the Wire)

Change-Id: If7e9ad2dcb8124e7d82ac837c5b62c0d09b00bcd

messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2011-12-14 00:46:27.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2011-12-14 00:46:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified

https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/quantum/111/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 233, 'date': '2011-12-14 00:46:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I think using add here is actually overkill and that we could use merge as long as we share the session with port_get.  I think what was actually happening here was an issue in the interaction with nova and sessions.  Add seems safer here anyhow.'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2011-12-14 00:46:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: No score

Just noticed a test does not pass with FakePlugin:

test_show_attachment_none_set_json (quantum.tests.unit.test_api.APITestV10)

It should be an easy fix. I'm not giving a -1 as I don't want to halt the review process since I'm going to sleep"}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2011-12-14 00:46:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

It does not look harmful to me. 

However, the problem Brad spotted does not occur when testing with FakePlugin. Attachments are correctly removed. Could this be something which has to do with MySQL backend?

Also, the fact that we need to pass the session to port_get look a bit weird to me. Why doesn't the error occur also when updating a port?"}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2011-12-14 00:46:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

damn, I started my review right before salv posted the comment.  I didn't see a test fail, but we'll look into it and push another fix if needed."}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2011-12-14 00:46:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, approved

Ok, I'm shipping this because we've seen known issues without this change, and this seems to be the more conservative approach. 

But it does make me nervous that I don't think we fully understand this.  With Brad's promise to look into this more post E-2, we'll go with it."}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2011-12-14 00:46:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Don't worry about that. 
I just pulled from master and all tests pass.
The failure I saw happened because I pressed by mistake CTRL+C while running the tests (I meant to do CTRL+C on another shell)"}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2011-12-14 00:46:27.000000000', 'message': 'Fix for bug 902175

We can't use merge if we're removing a field from the port object so use add
instead.  Also, pass the session to port_get so that we don't run into the
"this port is already bound to session x" error.

Change-Id: I54a8484c8f6429ad18fb0c5e088720d21fc16299
'}]
commit_message:
Fix for bug 902175

We can't use merge if we're removing a field from the port object so use add
instead.  Also, pass the session to port_get so that we don't run into the
"this port is already bound to session x" error.

Change-Id: I54a8484c8f6429ad18fb0c5e088720d21fc16299

'}, {'created': '2011-12-13 00:24:30.000000000', 'message': 'Add support for specifying an alternate Quantum host/port

Also change the Quantum support around a bit.. now if you want Quantum
networking you can specify "quantum" in enabled_services -- if you actually
want to run the service then you need to add "q-svc" to enabled services.

Finally, move some of the openvswitch plugin logic into the openvswitch block.

Change-Id: I4b45e40f9670d2288d7714864a76e83972bec2c0
'}]
commit_message:
Add support for specifying an alternate Quantum host/port

Also change the Quantum support around a bit.. now if you want Quantum
networking you can specify "quantum" in enabled_services -- if you actually
want to run the service then you need to add "q-svc" to enabled services.

Finally, move some of the openvswitch plugin logic into the openvswitch block.

Change-Id: I4b45e40f9670d2288d7714864a76e83972bec2c0

messages:
[{'account_id': 261, 'date': '2011-12-13 22:37:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

It looks from your code that the default op_status for the OVS plugin is going to be DOWN, which makes sense.

In this case, I've moved the default operational status for both ports and nets into test_config.

The expected value for a particular plugin can therefore be controlled in run_tests.py. 

It looks like you should just rebase to the latest changeset  for bp/api-operational-status and set the default operational statuses accordingly."}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2011-12-13 22:37:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Do not submit

commit_message:
blueprint operational-status-ovs-plugin

Implements operational status API for OVS plugin.   Uses existing
database model for operational status.  For network, status is always
up.  For a port, status is down unless there is an agent that
indicates that the port is active on its compute host.

Updated: use Salvatore's config hook to set default op-status for OVS
in OVS run_tests.py

Updated: fixed issue in _make_port_dict() found by Brad.

Change-Id: I0560cbde9dc69bd4211d9aaf12cef204df2f7664

commit_message:
Fix error when subnet doesn't have a cidr set

If it isn't set in the subnet just take it from the network_ref.

Change-Id: Id9b4a25b369884f4f4d5527b44d1215d3c244d70

commit_message:
bug 899767: fix vif-plugging with live migration

Expose vif_unplug method in virt layer, as the compute manager has to
explicitly call it on during live migration, so that network devices are
torn down even if the disk image is not.

Change-Id: Iae88c72f4fd2c7c097c23ef9e5f8fd392052f73e

commit_message:
Clean out old volumes from an existing VOLUME_GROUP if present

On subsequent runs of stack.sh clean out old volumes from $VOLUME_GROUP
(if it exists) and remove the iSCSI targets.  Also clean up the handling
when using a backing file rather than a physical disk for the PV.

VOLUME_NAME_PREFIX is used to determine which volumes to delete and to
set volume_name_template in nova.conf.

Change-Id: Iaf9effcc7e0ea5cdfad7bb180e67089e7f8b3583

subject: Fix tgtadm off by one error. Fixes bug #871278
messages:
[{'account_id': 360, 'date': '2011-10-26 18:08:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Chuck,

Getting syntax errors on this one:

pep8 nova/virt/libvirt/volume.py
nova/virt/libvirt/volume.py:114:13: E701 multiple statements on one line (colon)
nova/virt/libvirt/volume.py:115:24: E251 no spaces around keyword / parameter equals
nova/virt/libvirt/volume.py:116:29: E113 unexpected indentation
nova/virt/libvirt/volume.py:125:39: E111 indentation is not a multiple of four
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/bin/pep8", line 9, in <module>
    load_entry_point('pep8==0.6.0', 'console_scripts', 'pep8')()
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pep8.py", line 1346, in _main
    runner(path)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pep8.py", line 1027, in input_file
    errors = Checker(filename).check_all()
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pep8.py", line 953, in check_all
    for token in tokenize.generate_tokens(self.readline_check_physical):
  File "/usr/lib64/python2.7/tokenize.py", line 351, in generate_tokens
    ("<tokenize>", lnum, pos, line))
  File "<tokenize>", line 129
    locals())
    ^
IndentationError: unindent does not match any outer indentation level'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2011-11-09 23:30:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(1 inline comment)

Should be good to go once the typo is fixed."}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2011-11-10 08:18:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

The lun=0 vs lun=1 thing of the TargetAdmin subclasses

i.e.TgtAdm has this:

  '--lun=%d' % (lun + 1),  # lun0 is reserved

So, I think we should query the TargetAdmin helper for the LUN number it uses ... something like

  host_device = ("/dev/disk/by-path/ip-%s-iscsi-%s-lun-%d" %
                 (iscsi_properties['target_portal'],
                  iscsi_properties['target_iqn'],
                  iscsi.get_target_admin().get_lun_idx()))

Now, this is a bit odd because this is the client side using part of the server-side implementation to figure out where a LUN is going to show up. It makes sense, though, because it's the TargetAdmin deciding on the LUN index.

You'd think there'd be some way to query this with iscsiadm, would you? Bah!

Finally, there are two other places in the code base where we have 'lun-0' strings. Do either of them need a similar fix?'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2011-11-15 22:31:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

> Now, this is a bit odd because this is the client side using part of the server-side implementation to figure out where a LUN is going to show up. It makes sense, though, because it's the TargetAdmin deciding on the LUN index.

The purpose of the recent volume refactor was to not have to have client code importing server side code (it may eventually move into a separate project).  Instead, we could pass the lun back in the iscsi_properties from initialize_connection.  The logic could then be determined by the different driver on the server side."}, {'account_id': 24, 'date': '2011-12-13 18:46:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

better fix coming'}]

commit_message:
Sanitize EC2 manifests and image tarballs

Prevent potential directory traversal with malicious EC2 image tarballs,
by making sure the tarfile is safe before unpacking it. Fixes bug 894755

Prevent potential directory traversal with malicious file names in
EC2 image manifests. Fixes bug 885167

(cherry picked from commit ad3241929ea00569c74505ed002208ce360c667e)

Change-Id: If6109047307bd6e654ee9d1254f0d7f31cf741c1

commit_message:
Fix for bug 902175

Remove the gateway port when deleting the network (if it's the only one left),
and kill dnsmasq if the network is deleted.

Change-Id: If6b4798ddb4d21fe6c32ac20e6237494b799ecbd

commit_message:
Fix network forwarding rule initialization in QuantumManager

This moves the network init code from init to init_host() and breaks
the snat rule cmd out of driver.init_host().  The network_create call
can now just call the add_snat_rule function to set up the rule for
the network when it is created.

Change-Id: Id36dc42edd8b49938f85e16f16fce0416039fd50

commit_message:
Rename .nova-venv to .venv.

This simplifies a number of Jenkins jobs which currently, other
than directory names, could be the same for all OpenStack
projects. By renaming the virtualenv directory, the redundant
Jenkins virtualenv build and copy jobs can be eliminated.

Cherry-picked from 5235106e95681a2942a083aff7c00d385bd10489

Conflicts:

	.gitignore
	doc/source/devref/development.environment.rst

Change-Id: Ieaf1dac3207ecb34b911c7edcd2086809abdf49e

commit_message:
blueprint api-operational-status

Adds a new attribute expressing current operational status for port and network resources

Also includes:
- db models: changes to accomodate operational status concept
- unit tests: changes to include different validation functions for API v1.0 and v.1.1

This changeset does not include changes to the client library

NOTE: Addressing issue concerning unit tests for OVS plugin. API unit tests launched with
PLUGIN_DIR set to Cisco's plugin work fine as well.

Change-Id: I0c4f0f8a8c392bae75c668c28070364ca230f965

commit_message:
Sanitize EC2 manifests and image tarballs

Prevent potential directory traversal with malicious EC2 image tarballs,
by making sure the tarfile is safe before unpacking it. Fixes bug 894755

Prevent potential directory traversal with malicious file names in
EC2 image manifests. Fixes bug 885167

But I did want to say that identity-concepts.xml isn't part of a book file so it won't be built in the output. You probably want to edit the gettingstarted XML file instead."}, {'account_id': 964, 'date': '2011-10-26 19:53:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Like the image! Here are minor edits for the image itself: 
2 - Keystone authenticates Alices <-- should be Alice instead of Alices

Does she has the right to launch an instance? should be:

4- Keystone retrieve a service's endpoint should be:

Where is located the compute service? should be:
Where is the compute service located?"}, {'account_id': 1627, 'date': '2011-10-28 23:53:53.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1627, 'date': '2011-10-29 00:27:41.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 6, 'date': '2011-10-31 18:47:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Razique -the diagram is great, but makes it appear the user (Alice) is interacting directly with Keystone, when it's Nova that is doing all that interaction on "her" behalf. The diagram would be much less confusing to people if you had "nova" as a service in place of Alice, and then Alice interacting with Nova.'}, {'account_id': 1627, 'date': '2011-11-01 18:55:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 5, 'date': '2011-11-01 19:06:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Hi Razique - how can I get in touch with you? I think there are some modifications to the diagram that are needed and I started writing them up but it was a complicated to explain. Maybe a phone or Skype call would help?

Skype: ziad.saval"}, {'account_id': 1627, 'date': '2011-11-02 17:16:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 964, 'date': '2011-11-02 20:00:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Looks fabulous, great work.'}, {'account_id': 6, 'date': '2011-11-02 20:13:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

The scheme needs update since I saw with Ziad the correct flow.
I'll try to send the patch today !"}, {'account_id': 964, 'date': '2011-11-07 18:41:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: No score

Okay, thanks for letting us know.'}, {'account_id': 1627, 'date': '2011-11-07 21:04:36.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 1627, 'date': '2011-11-07 21:08:59.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 1627, 'date': '2011-11-07 21:15:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 1627, 'date': '2011-11-07 21:20:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 1627, 'date': '2011-11-07 21:23:43.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 11.'}, {'account_id': 6, 'date': '2011-11-07 21:58:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

this last diagram is just an arrow pointing left - I think maybe that's not what you intended..."}, {'account_id': 1627, 'date': '2011-11-07 22:33:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 12.'}, {'account_id': 6, 'date': '2011-11-07 22:36:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 1627, 'date': '2011-11-08 09:18:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 13.'}, {'account_id': 964, 'date': '2011-11-08 14:17:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Looks great. Do I need to wait for Ziad or can I +2 this?'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2011-11-08 19:42:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13:

It all looks correct to me, other than "The Catalog is sent" in step one... that doesn't happen today, but it might happen very, very, very soon. Today, that only occurs in the first arrow of Step 3. There's an active discussion on the mailing list about when service catalogs are returned what they should contain.

Also, the "Z" shaped flow is a little confusing to my sequence-diagram-oriented brain... but that's secondary to having the information out there :)'}, {'account_id': 5, 'date': '2011-11-09 03:42:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Hi Razique,

There are some potentially misleading labels/flows:
Step 1: there are three options here:
	1. Alice hits Nova directly and Nova responds with a 401 and the URL to Keystone.
	2. Alice hits Keystone directly providing credentials and a tenant (in which case the verification shown in step 2 is performed)
	3. Alice hits Keystone and does not specify a tenant. In which case she will get a token with no tenants specified. She would then need to call GET /v2.0/tenants.

Step 2: There is no check to see if Alice can access a specific service (Keystone does not even know Alice wants to launch a server yet). However, based on the credentials specified, the token returned may contain some service endpoints.

Step 3: I'm not sure what that is, so I'm not sure how to comment on it.

I think this may be close to the flow we have documented here: 

If you could replicate the flow in doc/design/flow_diagram.png using the cool graphics you have here, that would be more helpful for the docs."}, {'account_id': 1627, 'date': '2011-11-15 21:48:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 14.'}, {'account_id': 1627, 'date': '2011-11-15 22:54:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I haven't commited it, dunno how that review happened. I've seen with Ziad in order to update it and make it more accurate. Patch 15 will be the good one, 14 is a duplicate of 13"}, {'account_id': 1627, 'date': '2011-11-17 23:04:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 15.'}, {'account_id': 964, 'date': '2011-11-18 14:26:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Thanks for all the follow-through!'}, {'account_id': 1660, 'date': '2011-11-18 16:44:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15:

I think the diagram looks great, but I do have one small request. Steps 1 and 2 flow back and forth between Alice and Keystone in a very straightforward way. In step three though, the response from Keystone back to Alice flows to the right rather than back to the left. I was able to identify this after studying the diagram for a few minutes, but I think a label of some sort identifying the icon in step 3 as Alice would make it instantly identifiable. Maybe change the text in step 3 to "Keystone provides Alice her list of Services" and 7 to something along the lines of "The server reports the status to Alice"?'}, {'account_id': 1627, 'date': '2011-11-19 10:55:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 15:

I think you are right on that. The next patch has bigger step numbers, and I've renamed the steps 3 and 7 for better flow understanding"}, {'account_id': 1627, 'date': '2011-11-19 11:03:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 15:

Looks like I'll have to wait for others pending reivews to be updated, since I need to squash with previous commits - that would load that review with many other files."}, {'account_id': 1627, 'date': '2011-12-04 16:31:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 16.'}, {'account_id': 964, 'date': '2011-12-04 17:04:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

I think this will be a good addition to help those who like visuals better than text. The zig zag direction of the steps is the only controversial part, can we agree to use it as-is to help people now?'}, {'account_id': 1228, 'date': '2011-12-05 19:50:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 16: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Step 2 implies a GET /tenants call which does not return services. Instead it returns a list of tenants that the user has access to. Also, a new token is not issued on a GET /tenants call.

I think Alice needs to determine what tenant to authenticate against for a step 3 POST /tokens call.

So:
1 = POST /tokens no tenant ID
2 = GET /tenants
3 = POST /tokens with tenant ID
4 = your number 3
5 = you number 4
etc

Make sense?"}, {'account_id': 5, 'date': '2011-12-05 21:38:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16:

Razique - also see some of the updated docs here to explain the flows in sequence diagram format: http://docs.openstack.org/trunk/openstack-identity/admin/content/example-flows.html'}, {'account_id': 1627, 'date': '2011-12-06 08:48:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 16:

Sure, I'll try to stick closer to the updated flow :)
Let's hope we reach 20 reviews on that hehe"}, {'account_id': 1660, 'date': '2011-12-06 14:49:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

The more specific labeling throughout makes the flow through the diagram *much* easier to follow.'}, {'account_id': 964, 'date': '2011-12-13 14:22:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 16: Looks good to me, approved

Pushing this through as Razique has worked very hard on it and it will help others. Please modify if you see inaccuracies, but I think it's accurate and helpful."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2011-12-13 14:22:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/openstack-manuals/78/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2011-12-13 14:22:58.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}]

subject: Vm state management and error states
messages:
[{'account_id': 706, 'date': '2011-11-16 22:31:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(10 inline comments)

I'm a big fan of having a single feature per "merge proposal". I would love having more structured logic for determining which transition states are valid, but I'm not a big fan of the "vm_state timeout mechanism". Maybe we can work this out, but overall things will go smoother IMO if features are submitted individually.

Anyway, I hope my inline comments make sense as I made them over a couple hours today. Let me know if they don't make sense!'}, {'account_id': 1861, 'date': '2011-11-17 11:57:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (10 inline comments)

Thanks for your comments!
Yes, they make sense.
If necessary I can create new branches for different tasks'}, {'account_id': 1861, 'date': '2011-11-21 18:24:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (7 inline comments)

removing the timeout mechanism implementation from now. It could be interesting to keep a timeout mechanism for stages that do not depend on the virtualization layer, but I think we can discuss it in a different branch.'}, {'account_id': 1861, 'date': '2011-11-22 12:29:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1861, 'date': '2011-11-22 12:32:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

When rebasing my changes on top of master, I saw that a new implementation of the scheduler ERROR state was merged, but it had the same problem than my original implementation (gets instance_id from the arguments without checking the method when setting the instance to error: meaning that we could potentially set an instance to ERROR state when we were trying to schedule something else, as pointed by Brian), so I fixed that the same way that I fixed my original code.'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2011-12-01 05:53:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(4 inline comments)

Comments inline."}, {'account_id': 1861, 'date': '2011-12-12 14:56:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (4 inline comments)

doing the final changes to fix conflicts before sending a new version to review.'}, {'account_id': 1861, 'date': '2011-12-12 15:37:28.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2011-12-12 19:28:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: (2 inline comments)

This is looking great.   I have 2 issues before +1

1) there is a missing uuid in compute/manager (see inline comment)

2) I don't understand the removal of austin example db.  Was this just arbitrary cleanup because the file isn't used?

The other inline comment is just a thought, unneeded for me to  approve this merge."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2011-12-12 22:03:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(2 inline comments)

Overall, I like the direction of this patch. I've been working on lp897887 which is a result of allowing delete when the instance is still building. I proposed a branch (2257) but I may drop it in favor of this.

I've added a couple of inline comments.

I'd prefer if the allowed states were defined along with the appropriate API method in nova/compute/api.py. For instance, I noticed that there are no defined valid states for the delete method, but that took a lot of looking and searching, whereas it would have been obvious if it was defined with the method."}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2011-12-13 01:27:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2011-12-13 01:29:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Went ahead and updated the patchset with my fixes as david hasn't responded and I want to try to get this into e-2.

Johannes has offerred to do the refactor he requested, so this should be good to go in."}, {'account_id': 706, 'date': '2011-12-13 02:40:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Looks good from here.'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2011-12-13 02:55:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2011-12-13 03:04:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Verified

I didn't see the comments until now (I'm in UK and we have different time zones. Thanks for your fast review and the new commit!
David"}]

commit_message:
Vm state management and error states

this implements the blueprint nova-vm-state-management
It implements the following functionalities:
- Filter compute api calls according to state of the VM
(defined in compute/state_checker).
- Sets error state if the scheduler cannot allocate the VM in any host
- Handles the create/delete concurrency in the compute manager

Change-Id: Ie6d016b7d4781f70bb5967f204fa88a6412bd727

Also, the xenserver_install.sh script will need to warn about (or install) sqlalchemy on the xen server in order to be able to use this.

Thanks for doing this.. once it's clearer how to use it I think we should be good to go."}, {'account_id': 233, 'date': '2011-12-13 08:44:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

class VifPort:
^

You can run the unit tests against the ovs plugin (as well as the ovs specific unit tests) using:

PLUGIN_DIR=plugins/openvswitch-plugin/lib/quantum/plugins/openvswitch ./run_tests.sh -N

Should show any pep8 errors, too.'}, {'account_id': 233, 'date': '2011-12-13 08:44:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (2 inline comments)

commit_message:
Adds sqlalchemy support for ovs_quantum_plugin.

Fixes bug 890672

Allow to use any database as backend (supported by sqlalchemy).
Need to change ovs_quantum_plugin.ini and add variable sql_connection under DATABASE entry using specific sqlalchemy url schema (same as nova confs)

Change-Id: Ic490b09aad84c7f24d68064c18a8c1b33774cb05

commit_message:
blueprint services-insertion-wrapper

This utility offers a simplify way to insert and remove network services
in the path of the traffic to the server VMs, by splitting the network into two,
and having the service bridge between the two, in the process applying the service.
This model is called In-Path (Bump in the Wire)

Change-Id: I3d76262511d7f57c353d4de0c4022aa5953b0665

subject: Merging Floating Ips, Keypairs, and Security Groups into a single panel.
messages:
[{'account_id': 1816, 'date': '2011-12-12 20:34:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Keypair deletion doesn't seem to work.

I also don't love that the redirects for the various actions go to the old individual list pages rather than the new combined index page.

The way you've got these modals (like create security group) working is really buggy, and I'd rather they were just standard links rather than modals right now. We need to go through and do a pass on modals the right way rather than inserting more modals that only half-work. (e.g. opening then closing a modal, then trying to open it again causes it to not load the second time.)"}, {'account_id': 1205, 'date': '2011-12-12 21:10:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1205, 'date': '2011-12-12 22:07:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 543, 'date': '2011-12-12 23:44:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

commit_message:
support non "uec style" IMAGE_URLS

This adds support for image urls that end in .img.gz or .img.
The assumption is that they're a full disk image or a compressed
disk image.

Some examples:
 https://cloud-images.ubuntu.com/server/releases/11.10/release/ubuntu-11.10-server-cloudimg-i386-disk1.img
 http://launchpad.net/cirros/trunk/0.3.0/+download/cirros-0.3.0-x86_64-rootfs.img.gz
 http://launchpad.net/cirros/trunk/0.3.0/+download/cirros-0.3.0-x86_64-disk.img

Change-Id: I79b67b461fb02f2403dad3e15f630fa9817eb0db

revisions:
[{'created': '2011-12-09 23:53:23.000000000', 'message': 'fixed_ips by vif does not raise

It makes more sense if this method returns an 
empty array instead of raising when it finds no
ips. This lets the iteration over that array
handle the 0 case, and we can use a conditional on
the len(of the ips) if really needed. I'm not sure
that log is needed to say "No fixed IPs 
deallocated" or if that is an artifact of needing 
something to put in the exception handler.

Change-Id: Ib9f66affb5360fb11a3ab5f415a0e57602cec886
'}]
commit_message:
fixed_ips by vif does not raise

It makes more sense if this method returns an 
empty array instead of raising when it finds no
ips. This lets the iteration over that array
handle the 0 case, and we can use a conditional on
the len(of the ips) if really needed. I'm not sure
that log is needed to say "No fixed IPs 
deallocated" or if that is an artifact of needing 
something to put in the exception handler.

Change-Id: Ib9f66affb5360fb11a3ab5f415a0e57602cec886

reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 177, 'name': 'Alex Meade', 'email': 'mr.alex.meade@gmail.com', 'username': 'alex-meade'}, {'_account_id': 209, 'name': 'Josh Kearney', 'email': 'josh@jk0.org', 'username': 'jk0'}, {'_account_id': 616, 'name': 'Mark Washenberger', 'email': 'mark.washenberger@markwash.net', 'username': 'markwash'}, {'_account_id': 642, 'name': 'Matt Dietz', 'email': 'matthew.dietz@gmail.com', 'username': 'cerberus'}, {'_account_id': 688, 'name': 'Sandy Walsh', 'email': 'sandy.walsh@rackspace.com', 'username': 'sandy-walsh'}, {'_account_id': 1030, 'name': 'Chris Behrens', 'email': 'cbehrens@codestud.com', 'username': 'cbehrens'}, {'_account_id': 1132, 'name': 'Brian Waldon', 'email': 'brian@waldon.cc', 'username': 'bcwaldon'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 688, 'date': '2011-12-09 04:19:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Shouldn't we catch these exceptions in the notifier generally and update the database there? Then, not just run_instance() will get trapped, but all the other instance-related methods too."}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2011-12-09 15:45:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Sandy,

I think we're opting for explicit over implicit here. I personally don't think the notifier is the right place for the database update--I expect there to be a number of necessary reactions to a manager failure. I also expect them to be different for different failures. It seems like coding the reactions directly in the notify function would get awkward as the number of reactions grows.

That said, I'm not really thrilled about adding the db update for this into the manager. The way I see it, it would be better to publish a notification and expect a separate component to update presentation-oriented tables when it receives the notification. But I feel a bit shy about adding a long-lived component that subscribes to such notifications at the moment."}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2011-12-09 16:17:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2011-12-09 16:17:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Just fixing Alex's merge conflict."}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2011-12-09 17:13:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 642, 'date': '2011-12-09 17:50:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Generally ok with this patch, with one concern:

Are there plans to prune this table at any point? Huge tables that get migrated (and we'll find a reason at some point to change the schema for this table) are a nightmare in production deploys."}, {'account_id': 209, 'date': '2011-12-09 18:51:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2011-12-12 00:45:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Looks good to me, approved

Not sure what the 'code' is supposed to represent... but this is good enough for me for now.   Not sure whether nova should prune the table now and then or something external... Hmm."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2011-12-12 00:54:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-unittests/229/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-merge/620/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-pep8/1995/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2011-12-12 00:54:38.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}]

Add InstanceFault model

Functions to add and get instance faults
A single example of how faults should be added

commit_message:
blueprint api-framework-essex

Addressing Dan's comments.

This changeset provides:
- improved framework for API versioning, with separated controllers for each API version
- Taken from nova:'Resource' class in WSGI framework. This class is a container for serializers, deserializers and controller
- Better deserialization thanks to resource class. _parse_request_params has been removed
- Improved management of HTTP client errors
NOTE: this changeset does not update the framework used by API extensions.

Change-Id: I88a669ce418225c415e0da22e951762d0708e0a5

[{'created': '2011-12-09 21:38:25.000000000', 'message': 'Add MANIFEST.in and setup.cfg back.

These files are actually needed - without MANIFEST.in, files are missing
from the source tarball which is used in debian packaging. setup.cfg is
needed for configuration of the sphinx doc build commands.

Additionally, I added listings for the other files in the root to
MANIFEST.in so that the source tarball would be complete.

Change-Id: Ia0f281663b58baaf2ee23f627d4b1887d0eddfe9
'}]
commit_message:
Add MANIFEST.in and setup.cfg back.

These files are actually needed - without MANIFEST.in, files are missing
from the source tarball which is used in debian packaging. setup.cfg is
needed for configuration of the sphinx doc build commands.

Additionally, I added listings for the other files in the root to
MANIFEST.in so that the source tarball would be complete.

Change-Id: Ia0f281663b58baaf2ee23f627d4b1887d0eddfe9

commit_message:
Support rsyslog and RELP protocol

Configure rsyslog and services if SYSLOG=True in localrc.
Support logging to head node if SYSLOG_HOST has head note IP.
Use RELP for remote logging to prevent dropped records.

Change-Id: I960a1b4d2a24cbd9a900e68c758f362ec3d8c78e

revisions:
[{'created': '2011-12-07 15:52:11.000000000', 'message': "Port nova.flags to cfg

This modifies nova.flags to emulate gflags using the new cfg module
instead of optparse.

One side effect of this is that nova now has a --config-file argument
which allows a .ini style config file to be used instead of a gflags
style file.

Downstream packagers may choose to switch to using this new config
file by default, or stick with the gflags style file for now. We may,
in time, choose to deprecate --flagfile.

Obviously, this change is just a stepping stone towards having Nova use
the cfg API throughout the codebase. Next steps might include:

  - Adding a DEFINE_opt() function and starting to convert all the
    option definitions to the cfg.Opt schema types

  - Passing a ConfigOpts instance around rather than referring to the
    global flags.FLAGS variable

  - Adding a default .ini style config file with the default values
    commented out and an explanation of each option. This could
    potentially be autogenerated from the option schemas in the code.

  - Making use of option groups to organize options

  - In time, deprecating --flagfile

  - In time, also deprecating most of the options as CLI options and
    only allowing them to be set via config files

There are two hacks in the current code where we directly access the
OptionParser instance which is technically just a private implementation
detail of the ConfigOpts class:

  - We need to use optparse's disable_interspersed_args(). I think it's
    needed for nova-manage

  - We still need the gross hack for handling unknown CLI args. We
    should either make sure they are registered at startup, or just wait
    until we make them unavailable via the CLI before removing the hack.
    This would also allow us to remove the gross hack to allow CLI opts
    to be registered after the CLI args have been parsed.

One final note - the cfg module doesn't have support yet for multistr
opts where values are spread across the command line and config files.
This isn't a regression as it still works fine with the CLI and
--flagfile, and it should be straightforward to support later.

Change-Id: I173b99ffd645b8ac5babd68e5c2ed521b98ec2ca
"}, {'created': '2011-12-08 22:44:52.000000000', 'message': "Port nova.flags to cfg

This modifies nova.flags to emulate gflags using the new cfg module
instead of optparse.

One side effect of this is that nova now has a --config-file argument
which allows a .ini style config file to be used instead of a gflags
style file.

Downstream packagers may choose to switch to using this new config
file by default, or stick with the gflags style file for now. We may,
in time, choose to deprecate --flagfile.

Obviously, this change is just a stepping stone towards having Nova use
the cfg API throughout the codebase. Next steps might include:

  - Adding a DEFINE_opt() function and starting to convert all the
    option definitions to the cfg.Opt schema types

  - Passing a ConfigOpts instance around rather than referring to the
    global flags.FLAGS variable

  - Adding a default .ini style config file with the default values
    commented out and an explanation of each option. This could
    potentially be autogenerated from the option schemas in the code.

  - Making use of option groups to organize options

  - In time, deprecating --flagfile

  - In time, also deprecating most of the options as CLI options and
    only allowing them to be set via config files

There are two hacks in the current code where we directly access the
OptionParser instance which is technically just a private implementation
detail of the ConfigOpts class:

  - We need to use optparse's disable_interspersed_args(). I think it's
    needed for nova-manage

  - We still need the gross hack for handling unknown CLI args. We
    should either make sure they are registered at startup, or just wait
    until we make them unavailable via the CLI before removing the hack.
    This would also allow us to remove the gross hack to allow CLI opts
    to be registered after the CLI args have been parsed.

One final note - the cfg module doesn't have support yet for multistr
opts where values are spread across the command line and config files.
This isn't a regression as it still works fine with the CLI and
--flagfile, and it should be straightforward to support later.

Change-Id: I173b99ffd645b8ac5babd68e5c2ed521b98ec2ca
"}]
commit_message:
Port nova.flags to cfg

This modifies nova.flags to emulate gflags using the new cfg module
instead of optparse.

One side effect of this is that nova now has a --config-file argument
which allows a .ini style config file to be used instead of a gflags
style file.

Downstream packagers may choose to switch to using this new config
file by default, or stick with the gflags style file for now. We may,
in time, choose to deprecate --flagfile.

Obviously, this change is just a stepping stone towards having Nova use
the cfg API throughout the codebase. Next steps might include:

  - Adding a DEFINE_opt() function and starting to convert all the
    option definitions to the cfg.Opt schema types

  - Passing a ConfigOpts instance around rather than referring to the
    global flags.FLAGS variable

  - Adding a default .ini style config file with the default values
    commented out and an explanation of each option. This could
    potentially be autogenerated from the option schemas in the code.

  - Making use of option groups to organize options

  - In time, deprecating --flagfile

  - In time, also deprecating most of the options as CLI options and
    only allowing them to be set via config files

There are two hacks in the current code where we directly access the
OptionParser instance which is technically just a private implementation
detail of the ConfigOpts class:

  - We need to use optparse's disable_interspersed_args(). I think it's
    needed for nova-manage

  - We still need the gross hack for handling unknown CLI args. We
    should either make sure they are registered at startup, or just wait
    until we make them unavailable via the CLI before removing the hack.
    This would also allow us to remove the gross hack to allow CLI opts
    to be registered after the CLI args have been parsed.

One final note - the cfg module doesn't have support yet for multistr
opts where values are spread across the command line and config files.
This isn't a regression as it still works fine with the CLI and
--flagfile, and it should be straightforward to support later.

Change-Id: I173b99ffd645b8ac5babd68e5c2ed521b98ec2ca

Handle the 'instance' half of blueprint public-and-private-dns

Added a minimalist flat-file DNS example driver, MiniDNS.

Added tests for MiniDNS and a test that uses MiniDNS
to validate instance DNS creation.

commit_message:
Add templates for selected resource extensions.

Related to bug 852141; adds XML serialization and deserialization for
the following extensions:

* SecurityGroups (security_groups)
* SimpleTenantUsage (os-simple-tenant-usage)
* VirtualInterfaces (virtual_interfaces)
* Volumes (os-volumes)
* VolumeTypes (os-volume-types)

Change-Id: Ia3aef79c1912d3df14ab72bbdda3768ae131a19e
