ImportError: cannot import name fake_network_cache_model'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2011-12-02 10:57:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Random bunch of thoughts, sorry - gerrit isn't an ideal place for thinking out loud like this :-)

tl;dr summary, IMHO:

 - NetworkInfo should be versioned, and the compute service 
   should explicitly ask the network service via an RPC 
   call for whatever version it knows about.

 - The network service would have support for some limited 
   set of versions and just reject requests for versions it 
   doesn't know about.

 - The code to map from the DB tables to NetworkInfo should
   live in network/model.py. We'd use this code for doing
   the mapping both at runtime and in the migration.

 - Indeed, I'm not sure we really need to do it in a 
   migration. I'd imagine we'd make it so that if the
   NetworkInfo for an instance didn't exist in the cache,
   we'd just calculate it at runtime.

 - Consider whether an in-memory cache on the network side
   is sufficient. If it is to be a persistent cache in the
   DB, it also needs to be versioned. If the DB cache 
   contains a version we don't know about, then drop it and
   re-calculate.

 - The network service's RPC interface to fetch NetworkInfo
   should be able to do it for multiple instances in one
   call.

---

So, this NetworkInfo data structure is a representation of all the information related to an instance's virtual interfaces and the networks they're plugged into.

The primary source of this information is the vifs, networks, fixed_ips and floating_ips. I guess some of it may come from Quantum eventually? In any case, NetworkInfo is just the original canonical information transformed into a more convenient representation for the compute service.

The first thing I worry about is a future time where we'll be able to do rolling upgrades. That would probably mean allowing older versions of compute to run with newer versions of network. (And in HA mode, older versions of network running alongside newer versions). What I think we'd need for that is compute to be able to ask network for a specific version of this NetworkInfo data structure. The network service would be able to satisfy requests for some for older versions of the structure, and reject requests for any other versions.

The next thing that scares me is that you've a bunch of code to map from the canonical data to NetworkInfo in a DB migration. Will there be a similar bunch of code to do the same thing at runtime? Can we not use the runtime code in the migration too? It would also be nice for this code to live in network/model.py so you can more easily see the relationship between NetworkInfo and its primary source.

And then there's the optimization aspect of the compute service pulling NetworkInfo directly from the cache in the DB ...

Are we trying to eliminate/reduce network roundtrips in order for compute to fetch NetworkInfo? If so, we still have a roundtrip to the DB if the cache is in the DB. Is an in-memory cache in compute what we really need here?

Or is it that when you're listing many VMs, we have a roundtrip for each VM to get the NetworkInfo? Could that not be solved by just have a network service API that returns NetworkInfo for multiple instances at once?

Or is it that NetworkInfo itself is expensive to compute because it involves querying multiple tables etc. If so, would an in-memory cache in the network service not be better?"}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2011-12-02 13:42:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(1 inline comment)

"}, {'account_id': 191, 'date': '2011-12-02 17:04:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

tl;dr summary, IMHO:

- NetworkInfo should be versioned, and the compute service
should explicitly ask the network service via an RPC
call for whatever version it knows about.

- The network service would have support for some limited
set of versions and just reject requests for versions it
doesn't know about.

i chose not to do this here. There is already a blueprint with a much broader scope for this: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/formalized-message-structures

- The code to map from the DB tables to NetworkInfo should
live in network/model.py. We'd use this code for doing
the mapping both at runtime and in the migration.

This at first seems like it would make sense, but the various network implementations should package up the network_info such that nova understands it, not the other way around. Doing this in the network manager makes more sense. There will be different network managers for each implementation and they have knowledge of both nova and any external service


- Indeed, I'm not sure we really need to do it in a
migration. I'd imagine we'd make it so that if the
NetworkInfo for an instance didn't exist in the cache,
we'd just calculate it at runtime.

The cache exists because we can't calculate at runtime: certain calls (like nova list) will fail. If the cache exists and is empty, that call will still fail.

- Consider whether an in-memory cache on the network side
is sufficient. If it is to be a persistent cache in the
DB, it also needs to be versioned. If the DB cache
contains a version we don't know about, then drop it and
re-calculate.

The problem with any of this being stored on the network side is having to go through rpc to get to it. Imagine a call to list details on 1000 instances. 1000 RPC calls is failmode. instance_get_all() on the zone local nova db is many times more efficient.

- The network service's RPC interface to fetch NetworkInfo
should be able to do it for multiple instances in one
call.

This is something I've considered as well, but then we have to include pagination and message size limits. Keeping a "cache" on the compute side that can be kept up to date as things change for each individual instance is simpler and more efficient.
---

So, this NetworkInfo data structure is a representation of all the information related to an instance's virtual interfaces and the networks they're plugged into.

-yep

The primary source of this information is the vifs, networks, fixed_ips and floating_ips. I guess some of it may come from Quantum eventually? In any case, NetworkInfo is just the original canonical information transformed into a more convenient representation for the compute service.

-yes it will come from quantum. That is actually what prompted this: not being able to rely on foreign keys in the nova db anymore. It is a bit more than the "original canonical information".

The first thing I worry about is a future time where we'll be able to do rolling upgrades. That would probably mean allowing older versions of compute to run with newer versions of network. (And in HA mode, older versions of network running alongside newer versions). What I think we'd need for that is compute to be able to ask network for a specific version of this NetworkInfo data structure. The network service would be able to satisfy requests for some for older versions of the structure, and reject requests for any other versions.

-the format that this is stored should not necessarily matter. If it changes, that too shouldn't matter. What I'm hoping to do is over time have functions which exist to get at the data. As long as the functions don't change, the underlying structure can be completely different from one version to the next and the caller need not care. Also being as closely tied to dictionaries as it is makes it simple to attempt grabbing keys from ad_hoc without raising. When the version discussion comes up for that other blueprint, I'm almost convinced that it need not apply to this model. As long we write the new version such that the old model can hydrate (which isn't difficult) we're golden. This is something using ad_hoc solves.

The next thing that scares me is that you've a bunch of code to map from the canonical data to NetworkInfo in a DB migration. Will there be a similar bunch of code to do the same thing at runtime? Can we not use the runtime code in the migration too? It would also be nice for this code to live in network/model.py so you can more easily see the relationship between NetworkInfo and its primary source.

-yes. The other merge I referred to will include code in the network managers to update the cache whenever anything changes on the network side of things. I'm also considering dropping the migration altogether and just having compute hosts kick off the cache build for their instances upon boot as a part of the init process. Thoughts there? Either way it's expensive. I can't decide whether 1 really nasty migration is better than every compute host boot or reboot being nasty.

And then there's the optimization aspect of the compute service pulling NetworkInfo directly from the cache in the DB ...

Are we trying to eliminate/reduce network roundtrips in order for compute to fetch NetworkInfo? If so, we still have a roundtrip to the DB if the cache is in the DB. Is an in-memory cache in compute what we really need here?

-The purpose of this "cache" is to provide api with an efficient way to get at network information. In the future a more elegant memory based cache may make sense, but where it lives will need to be determined, as well has how precaching works. This solutions solves the problem creating by untying the network related foreign keys in the nova db, such that things will work the same for both the internal and external network implementations.

Or is it that when you're listing many VMs, we have a roundtrip for each VM to get the NetworkInfo? Could that not be solved by just have a network service API that returns NetworkInfo for multiple instances at once?

-the problem here is that even a single rpc call would have many db calls on the other side. Using this cache, it's  just a single call to instance_get_all() or whatever it's called, and all the cache info is eagerloaded on each instance. Hard to beat that efficiency.

Or is it that NetworkInfo itself is expensive to compute because it involves querying multiple tables etc. If so, would an in-memory cache in the network service not be better?

-i guess we just agreed. An in memory cache is always going to be faster but this would still mean many lookups. A 1000 instance list would still hit that cache 1000 times.


-I'm not discounting the use of in memory caches. This cache can easily be replaced with one in the future. API would just hit the memory cache instead of using the the cache foreign key ref on instance.'}, {'account_id': 191, 'date': '2011-12-02 20:25:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I have a small nit: I personally prefer to name method names with a verb that describes the action they are performing (e.g., def add_*, get_*, create_*). This makes things more clear (self-documenting) when you're importing from another package and there is no code context to see what a particular method or function might do.

As such, I'd prefer to see the functions in fake_network_cache_model.py be prefaced with something like "make_*" or "create_*"

This is, of course, a personal preference and I am not yet familiar enough with the common practices in OpenStack to know how well this meshes with the preferred approach for this project.

Regardless, this change is shaping up nicely!'}, {'account_id': 191, 'date': '2011-12-08 20:15:55.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 17.'}, {'account_id': 385, 'date': '2011-12-08 20:23:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 17: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

commit_message:
Adds network model and network info cache.

The next merge will prepopulate the cache, and use the model to keep the
cache up to date.
I realize "cache" is a bit of a stretch for what this is doing.

blueprint network-info-model
blueprint compute-network-info

Change-Id: I0f0f4ba3de1310e1ff89239dab6ea8e24c85f2c8

[{'created': '2011-12-09 13:59:35.000000000', 'message': "Log it when we get a lock

Currently, we log it when we attempt to acquire a log, but we don't
mention it when we succesfully do acquire it. This makes people think
it's stuck.

This patch logs the succesful acquiry of locks.

Change-Id: I3b49ff331641ceafa46c93d8f5233c85fe45e5e2
"}]
commit_message:
Log it when we get a lock

Currently, we log it when we attempt to acquire a log, but we don't
mention it when we succesfully do acquire it. This makes people think
it's stuck.

This patch logs the succesful acquiry of locks.

Change-Id: I3b49ff331641ceafa46c93d8f5233c85fe45e5e2

commit_message:
Make QuantumManager no longer depend on the projects table

Vish said that creating projects in a test is a no-no and that the
QuantumManager shouldn't be relying on the projects table anyways (since
they're now in keystone)..

Change-Id: I4d5c28746d0d2b4a9aaf7feb0a38792473d16847

commit_message:
Rename .nova-venv to .venv.

This simplifies a number of Jenkins jobs which currently, other
than directory names, could be the same for all OpenStack
projects. By renaming the virtualenv directory, the redundant
Jenkins virtualenv build and copy jobs can be eliminated.

Change-Id: Ieaf1dac3207ecb34b911c7edcd2086809abdf49e

subject: Add ability to see deleted and active records.
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 100, 'name': 'Johannes Erdfelt', 'email': 'johannes@erdfelt.com', 'username': 'johannes.erdfelt'}, {'_account_id': 209, 'name': 'Josh Kearney', 'email': 'josh@jk0.org', 'username': 'jk0'}, {'_account_id': 475, 'name': 'Rick Harris', 'email': 'rick.harris@rackspace.com', 'username': 'rconradharris'}, {'_account_id': 679, 'name': 'Kevin L. Mitchell', 'email': 'klmitch@mit.edu', 'username': 'klmitch'}, {'_account_id': 706, 'name': 'Brian Lamar', 'email': 'brian.lamar@rackspace.com', 'username': 'blamar'}, {'_account_id': 1132, 'name': 'Brian Waldon', 'email': 'brian@waldon.cc', 'username': 'bcwaldon'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 209, 'date': '2011-12-07 17:02:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Nice work!'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2011-12-07 17:29:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 209, 'date': '2011-12-07 17:29:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 706, 'date': '2011-12-07 21:13:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

If you get a moment, could you respond to the feedback on the bug you filed? Thanks!'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2011-12-07 21:17:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

I like this approach, even in preference to Waldon's suggestion..."}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2011-12-07 21:24:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

It still feels odd to use this context field to solve two problems:

1) Are you authorized to view deleted entities?
2) What do you want to see in your query, only deleted, only active, or both?

I think the answer to question 1 belongs in the context, since that's constant once you've authenticated. The answer to question 2 can change from query to query, and we shouldn't change the context that often.

I guess another question I should ask is should we allow anyone to view deleted entities? The existing behavior would say no, while this implementation says yes.

And I would appreciate it if you would split your --short-pep8 change into a different merge prop. It's totally unrelated."}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2011-12-07 21:34:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> It still feels odd to use this context field to solve two problems:
> 1) Are you authorized to view deleted entities? 2) What do you want to see in your query, only deleted, only active, or both?

I agree that it's odd and I'd be all for (down-the-road) changing to a more sensible behavior.

This patch aims to fix the bug with minimal risk to the current code. It does this by being (relatively) easy to spot check since the state is represented by a single variable, and by maintaining strict backwards compatibility (to the point of leaving seemingly-broken-behavior in place--those can be addressed later).

I'd vote we get this patch in soon, and then work towards something similar to what you propose in a follow on patch.

> And I would appreciate it if you would split your --short-pep8 change into a different merge prop. It's totally unrelated.

Ok."}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2011-12-07 21:45:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

So you are changing the behavior that we currently have where you can't see deleted records unless context.read_deleted is True (which means you're an admin). Am I correct in assuming you want to get change that behavior?"}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2011-12-07 21:53:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> So you are changing the behavior that we currently have where you can't see deleted records unless context.read_deleted is True (which means you're an admin). Am I correct in assuming you want to get change that behavior?

Hopefully, I'm not *changing* any existing behavior; rather, I'm adding additional behavior in the form of read_deleted="yes".  

In all of the places where the original code would have seen *only* deleted or *only* active records, that's still the case.

Future code (the running_deleted_instance_reaper) will make use of the additional read_deleted="yes" functionality.'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2011-12-07 21:54:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2011-12-07 21:59:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2011-12-07 22:02:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

One sec, fixing a bad rebase...'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2011-12-07 22:10:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2011-12-07 22:13:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 209, 'date': '2011-12-07 22:17:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2011-12-08 15:29:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

(1 inline comment)

Ok, so I want to be clear that I still want to take this in the direction I brought up earlier. However, I am okay with this going in as it is. The main thing I didn't want to lose was the current behavior of preventing users from seeing deleted records if they aren't an admin. We still have the behavior assuming the client of the db api doesn't pass in read_deleted='yes'. Also, please see the one inline comment I made."}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2011-12-08 16:29:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2011-12-08 22:50:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me, approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2011-12-08 23:01:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-unittests/204/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-merge/598/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-pep8/1973/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2011-12-08 23:01:27.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}]

'}, {'created': '2011-12-07 22:10:07.000000000', 'message': 'Add ability to see deleted and active records.

Fixes bug #900564

Changes `Context`.`read_deleted` from a bool to an enum string with values
"yes" (can read deleted records), "no" (cannot read deleted records), and
"only" (can only see deleted records, for backwards compatibility).

Change-Id: Ic81db3664c33f23f751b73973782efb06fce90d9
'}]
commit_message:
Add ability to see deleted and active records.

Fixes bug #900564

Changes `Context`.`read_deleted` from a bool to an enum string with values
"yes" (can read deleted records), "no" (cannot read deleted records), and
"only" (can only see deleted records, for backwards compatibility).

Change-Id: Ic81db3664c33f23f751b73973782efb06fce90d9

commit_message:
Lock keystone to specific commit in pip-requires

We'll use commit b9dde8d0e317203e349b8e4bca5bc9923c11974e. This will help ensure our tests don't fail due to a changing keystone trunk

Change-Id: Ie9b8f0bd13b974817e8ce7de08033ab3f5bcce0c

subject: Comment out keystone from pip-requires. Fixes bug #901018.
messages:
[{'account_id': 360, 'date': '2011-12-07 14:26:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2011-12-07 15:30:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Do not submit

As mentioned on the bug report, I'd prefer not to do this and to fix the issue with Keystone...

The pip-requires file should list dependent libs for all of the tests, including the functional integration ones.

-jay"}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2011-12-07 15:32:29.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2011-12-07 15:36:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Jay. I respectfully disagree here. Integration testing should be the realm of higher level testing (SmokeStack/Torpedo/Tempest, etc). IMHO requiring keystone to be pip installed by default is a dependency "house of cards" that is probably always going to cause instability when running unit tests.

As much as possible unit tests should always run. Regardless of whether the latest keystone build works!

As far as I can tell Glance is the only Openstack project to couple itself to keystone in this manner.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2011-12-07 16:23:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

I have to say, I'm with Dan here; unit tests should always be able to be run, even if, say, Keystone can't be installed for some reason.  Given that Keystone is not required to run Glance, it should not be required to run the tests."}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2011-12-07 16:28:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Guys, see my comment on the bug report...'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2011-12-08 17:58:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Abandoned'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2011-12-07 14:24:53.000000000', 'message': 'Remove keystone from pip-requires. Fixes #901018.

Change-Id: Ib3412dbeab6ad93845ca6b063804caebf4e39c98
'}, {'created': '2011-12-07 14:26:30.000000000', 'message': 'Remove keystone from pip-requires. Fixes bug #901018.

Change-Id: Ib3412dbeab6ad93845ca6b063804caebf4e39c98
'}, {'created': '2011-12-07 15:32:29.000000000', 'message': "Comment out keystone from pip-requires. Fixes bug #901018.

This type of test is integration level testing and we really shouldn't
have it enabled by default.

Change-Id: Ib3412dbeab6ad93845ca6b063804caebf4e39c98
"}]
commit_message:
Comment out keystone from pip-requires. Fixes bug #901018.

This type of test is integration level testing and we really shouldn't
have it enabled by default.

Change-Id: Ib3412dbeab6ad93845ca6b063804caebf4e39c98

Force using the melange branch of openstack.common.

This ensures will ensure that melange will always be installable
until openstack.common gets bootstrapped and the api's commited to.

Change-Id: Ifb99dea4acc70324a1450825efc68c862cb81dd3

commit_message:
Fix a notification bug when creating instances

Fixes a notifier bug that caused 'launched_at' to be empty and
state to be reported as 'building', due to failure to refresh
instance data prior to generating the notification.  Fixes
bug 834867.

(cherry picked from commit 57e73d374843cade854f07a228192c4f496507ff)

Change-Id: I70fbf3c67407c67b69040ee481ca6d51212cc55d

revisions:
[{'created': '2011-12-08 15:41:21.000000000', 'message': 'Bug #897091: "nova actions" fails with HTTP 400 / TypeError if a server action has been performed

Fix code in Controller.action that was overwriting the definition of the
actions method with a dictionary.  This meant that 'nova actions' would fail
if 'nova reboot' had previously been called.

Added two tests, one for the actions call in general, and one for this
failure mode specifically.

(cherry picked from commit 4a76167e354eed4aa98232fbf6c845f86ce4cf22)

Change-Id: I695bb5c4dcfba96a5aba54125a8f3163e1a6a193
'}]
commit_message:
Bug #897091: "nova actions" fails with HTTP 400 / TypeError if a server action has been performed

Fix code in Controller.action that was overwriting the definition of the
actions method with a dictionary.  This meant that 'nova actions' would fail
if 'nova reboot' had previously been called.

Added two tests, one for the actions call in general, and one for this
failure mode specifically.

(cherry picked from commit 4a76167e354eed4aa98232fbf6c845f86ce4cf22)

Change-Id: I695bb5c4dcfba96a5aba54125a8f3163e1a6a193

revisions:
[{'created': '2011-12-07 15:33:22.000000000', 'message': 'Add new cfg module

As discussed on the mailing list and described here:

  http://wiki.openstack.org/CommonConfigModule

The module implements an API for defining configuration options and
reading values for those options that a user may have set in a config
file or on the command line.

The module will be part of openstack-common and glance will consume
it from there once openstack-common makes a release with an API
compatibility commitment.

Change-Id: Ib604c3de75d9066cd913c2de3007024b1f5ec9f8
'}]
commit_message:
Add new cfg module

As discussed on the mailing list and described here:

  http://wiki.openstack.org/CommonConfigModule

The module implements an API for defining configuration options and
reading values for those options that a user may have set in a config
file or on the command line.

The module will be part of openstack-common and glance will consume
it from there once openstack-common makes a release with an API
compatibility commitment.

revisions:
[{'created': '2011-12-06 15:07:32.000000000', 'message': 'A more secure root-wrapper alternative

Alternative to using a sudoers file to limit which commands can be run as
root in Nova. This one makes use of command filters defined in Nova code
itself, which can be customized to deeply inspect command arguments before
allowing a command to be executed.

This change puts the infrastructure in place, together with command filters
that replicate the level of filtering provided by a sudoers file (no deep
argument inspection yet). An example of an advanced filter (RegExpFilter) is
also provided. This new root wrapper is not active by default (root_helper
still defaults to "sudo"). Implements blueprint nova-rootwrap.

Change-Id: I7ad723b55e9446758876f21b4fbb09374a910425

commit_message:
A more secure root-wrapper alternative

Alternative to using a sudoers file to limit which commands can be run as
root in Nova. This one makes use of command filters defined in Nova code
itself, which can be customized to deeply inspect command arguments before
allowing a command to be executed.

This change puts the infrastructure in place, together with command filters
that replicate the level of filtering provided by a sudoers file (no deep
argument inspection yet). An example of an advanced filter (RegExpFilter) is
also provided. This new root wrapper is not active by default (root_helper
still defaults to "sudo"). Implements blueprint nova-rootwrap.

Change-Id: I7ad723b55e9446758876f21b4fbb09374a910425

revisions:
[{'created': '2011-12-07 18:21:58.000000000', 'message': "Fix race condition in XenAPI list_instances

Fixes bug 887708

The XenAPI list_instances method assumes that the VM refs returned
by VM.get_all are still valid when calling VM.get_record. This isn't
necessarily true since there is a race with deleting instances. The
fix is to ignore instances that return HANDLE_INVALID since they
don't exist anymore

Change-Id: Ib94adb6d21b6b55e7b26fc1da52ed46d9dba8275
"}, {'created': '2011-12-07 20:36:56.000000000', 'message': 'Fix race condition in XenAPI when using <object>.get_all

Fixes bug 887708

There are a handful of places where <object>.get_all is followed by a
<object>.get_record calls that are potentially racey. This patch fixes
all of these cases to use common code that is tolerant of HANDLE_INVALID
errors that would be indicative of a race between get_all and delete

Change-Id: Ib94adb6d21b6b55e7b26fc1da52ed46d9dba8275
'}, {'created': '2011-12-07 21:27:28.000000000', 'message': 'Fix race condition in XenAPI when using <object>.get_all

Fixes bug 887708

There are a handful of places where <object>.get_all is followed by a
<object>.get_record calls that are potentially racey. This patch fixes
all of these cases to use common code that is tolerant of HANDLE_INVALID
errors that would be indicative of a race between get_all and delete

Change-Id: Ib94adb6d21b6b55e7b26fc1da52ed46d9dba8275
'}]
commit_message:
Fix race condition in XenAPI when using <object>.get_all

Fixes bug 887708

There are a handful of places where <object>.get_all is followed by a
<object>.get_record calls that are potentially racey. This patch fixes
all of these cases to use common code that is tolerant of HANDLE_INVALID
errors that would be indicative of a race between get_all and delete

Change-Id: Ib94adb6d21b6b55e7b26fc1da52ed46d9dba8275

commit_message:
Clean up snapshot metadata

- Removed image_state from compute api snapshot (only needed by ec2/s3)
- Only set backup_type when image_type is 'backup'
- Add testing to verify snapshots/backups get the correct metadata

Change-Id: Ib5461f9aa790d7ed5629c591bbe1510443dbc2aa

commit_message:
Refactors periodic tasks to use a decorator.

Additional work:

    1. Added support for tasks being scheduled at differing rates via the
       `ticks_between_runs` argument.

    2. Fixed `reclaim_queued_deletes` so that it doesn't run if
       `FLAGS.reclaim_instance_interval` is 0.

Change-Id: I18c01baf07bd06301a6fe26a7b29dc2452a4fa96

subject: First steps towards consolidating testing infrastructure
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 7, 'name': 'Jay Pipes', 'email': 'jaypipes@gmail.com', 'username': 'jaypipes'}, {'_account_id': 321, 'name': 'Lorin Hochstein', 'email': 'lorinh@gmail.com', 'username': 'lorinh'}, {'_account_id': 357, 'name': 'Devin Carlen', 'email': 'devin@openstack.org', 'username': 'devcamcar'}, {'_account_id': 518, 'name': 'Soren Hansen', 'email': 'soren@linux2go.dk', 'username': 'soren'}, {'_account_id': 679, 'name': 'Kevin L. Mitchell', 'email': 'klmitch@mit.edu', 'username': 'klmitch'}, {'_account_id': 693, 'name': 'Christopher MacGown', 'email': 'chris@pistoncloud.com', 'username': '0x44'}, {'_account_id': 1132, 'name': 'Brian Waldon', 'email': 'brian@waldon.cc', 'username': 'bcwaldon'}, {'_account_id': 1247, 'name': 'Mark McLoughlin', 'email': 'markmc@redhat.com', 'username': 'markmc'}, {'_account_id': 1394, 'name': 'mcgrue', 'username': 'mcgrue'}, {'_account_id': 1801, 'name': 'Duncan McGreggor', 'email': 'duncan.mcgreggor@rackspace.com', 'username': 'oubiwann'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 1801, 'date': '2011-11-23 21:10:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

A quick note: 

The code here represents a first step, and is pushed for a review in order to keep the review branches small. 

Next steps include:
 * moving nova.test to nova.testing.base
 * moving other fakes in various subpackages into nova.testing.fake
 * removing redundancies in testing base classes
 * creating new testing base classes, as required for ease of maintenance and contributions
 * separating out functional tests from unit tests'}, {'account_id': 321, 'date': '2011-11-24 15:16:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

The changes look good. 

It would be helpful if there was a linked blueprint with a high-level description of the intended test refactoring.'}, {'account_id': 1801, 'date': '2011-11-27 22:19:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Lorin,

I had the same concern, but didn't actually motivate to do it... until now :-) I've created it here:
  https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/consolidate-testing-infrastructure

Thanks!"}, {'account_id': 1394, 'date': '2011-11-28 23:56:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

I am super in favor of incremental work on big tasks, and of testing infrastructure consolidation.'}, {'account_id': 693, 'date': '2011-11-29 00:07:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Looks good to me.'}, {'account_id': 321, 'date': '2011-11-29 03:05:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Duncan:

For future reference, you can reference by name to get a link, like this:

blueprint consolidate-testing-infrastructure'}, {'account_id': 357, 'date': '2011-11-30 00:12:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2011-11-30 00:14:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Fails

Build Failed 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-unittests/119/ : FAILURE 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-pep8/1889/ : FAILURE 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-merge/514/ : This change was unable to be automatically merged with the current state of the repository. Please rebase your change and upload a new patchset.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2011-11-30 01:23:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Hi!

Couple things...

AFAIK, po files should not be changed in normal code changesets. There is automation code that updates the translation catalogs and templates and there should be no manual changes to po files needed.

Secondly, is there a reason to call the directory "testing" instead of "tests"? All the other core projects use the "tests" directory to put stubs, testing utils, etc...

-jay'}, {'account_id': 1801, 'date': '2011-11-30 02:19:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Thanks, Jay -- I'll revert the changes to the po files.

As for tests vs. testing:

1) the "tests" directories are where actual unit tests go;

2) in "testing" there are no unit tests; it's infrastructure, for unit tests, not unit tests themselves'}, {'account_id': 1801, 'date': '2011-11-30 02:39:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

To fix the Jenkins fail, I merged the latest changes from master and resolved the conflicts. 

I also removed the changes to the ./po files.

When I resubmitted for review, it created a new one here:
  Change-Id: I9a441ccf91fd006464c2b5aa957714c1ebea40c1

Not sure what to do about this, regarding the already-received reviews...'}, {'account_id': 1801, 'date': '2011-11-30 03:23:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2011-11-30 04:05:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Hey Duncan,

Since the commit message here will be used when merged into master, would you mind cleaning it up a bit? I would suggest replacing it with the following text. All you have to do is git commit -a --amend and you can rewrite the commit message.


First steps towards consolidating testing infrastructure

This commit begins to implement blueprint consolidate-testing-infrastructure by adding a 'testing' submodule.

Change-Id: I04bf860bc386bd2016e7dbc5a6f6ef7379a855bb"}, {'account_id': 1801, 'date': '2011-11-30 04:31:29.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1801, 'date': '2011-11-30 04:32:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Thanks Brian, done.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2011-11-30 04:36:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Thanks for updating that, Duncan. As for Jay's question about using 'testing' vs 'tests': I don't think I'm sold on having two testing-related modules. I understand that you're saying 'tests' is for tests and 'testing' is for infrastructure code, but tests could also fit under 'testing.' I think I would really prefer to keep it all under 'tests' as that's what the majority of python projects use."}, {'account_id': 1801, 'date': '2011-11-30 04:57:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Hey Brian, here are some clarifying comments:

Well, "testing" is not actually my invention ;-) It's something that I've adopted from other projects I have worked on and has kept my own projects very clean and easily understood by newcomers.

Some of the best-organized code bases I have seen don't put all the tests in a top-level "tests" directory; they put top-level tests there (e.g., nova would put test modules in nova/tests for modules in nova/). Then, each subpackage, gets its own "tests" directory with tests specific to that subpackage (e.g., nova/volume modules would have nova/volume/tests, which would contain test_api.py, test_driver.py, test_iscsi.py, etc.). This has many benefits, not the least of which is clarity, and test module namespace cleanliness.

As such, there are many places where "tests" could occur, none any better than another to contain testing infrastructure... thus the "testing" subpackage.

Even if there is only one location for all tests, don't you think that it makes sense to keep just unit and functional tests together, without cluttering the tests directory? This is very much akin to having a "utils.py" module, or "utils" subpackage, for keeping that sort of functionality from cluttering the project namespace.

Finally, we may get to the point (after this refactoring) where the testing infrastructure we're setting up is useful for glace, swift, horizon, etc., at which point we might want to move generalized testing infrastructure from nova.testing to nova.common.testing (or whatever Python namespace is/will be set for nova-common). And if we want to override the common defaults with subclasses of our own, again, it would make the most sense to do all this in a nova.testing subpackage, since it is not stuff that is tested, but rather stuff that is used to build tests. 

Perhaps the best analogy is the unittest package from the standard library: what we're doing here is extending that, and adding supporting code for our own unit tests. As such, a great name would be nova.unittest. Due to the problems of namespace collision, though, it's probably best to choose another name... like "testing".

Hope this helps!'}, {'account_id': 1801, 'date': '2011-11-30 05:53:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Jay, Brian:

What about adding a nova/testing/README that explains that this subpackage is the container for code that is utilized to create unit tests (nova's own "unittest" package), not for unit tests themselves. This way, as new-comers start poking around, we have something in place to eliminate their confusion?'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2011-11-30 15:10:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Hi Duncan,

Thanks for your discussion about the testing vs test directory. I understand your viewpoint better now.

My main concern was really about consistency with the other OpenStack core projects. I've seen projects that have tests/ directories in each sub-module. I don't really have a preference one way or the other. My main goal is consistency.

So, I suppose my final vote on this is that I think a discussion of changing from a monolithic tests/ directory to a tests/ directory in each module should probably be a discussion/vote that happens on the mailing list...

I don't really buy into the argument that a separate testing directory better indicates that "fakes" or "utils" for testing versus just including a fakes.py or utils.py in the tests/ directory. But, it's not all that big of a deal to me if that changes. :)

Cheers,
-jay'}, {'account_id': 1801, 'date': '2011-12-01 21:10:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Hey folks, there was a conflict with the master by the time all the approvals came in.

Does everyone need to do their reviews of this branch again?'}, {'account_id': 321, 'date': '2011-12-02 20:34:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 1801, 'date': '2011-12-05 19:26:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Ping ;-)'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2011-12-05 19:41:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

The discussion between you and Jay is interesting.  I have to confess that "testing" as a subpackage name still bothers me, however; I really would prefer that we have a different name, though I don't really have one to suggest off the top of my head.  In lieu of that, I would *highly* recommend some sort of documentation for the testing infrastructure.  It could be a README in the testing directory, an addition to the top-level README or HACKING, or even a separate README.unittests or something.  (Whatever you pick, there should probably be a reference to it in the top-level HACKING, at a minimum...)'}, {'account_id': 1801, 'date': '2011-12-05 20:04:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Thanks, Kevin -- working on that now.'}, {'account_id': 1801, 'date': '2011-12-05 21:50:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 1801, 'date': '2011-12-05 21:52:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Per the review comment, I have created a README.rst in nova/testing:
 * It currently has a brief introduction
 * Sections for future content are stubbed and marked "to be done" (TBD)
 * I've added a link to the blueprint (temporary addition only) so that readers know what's coming, what's in progress, etc.

I have also updated the HACKING file, including the following changes:
 * Removed trailing whitespace
 * Renamed HACKING to HACKING.rst so that it will render wherever ReST is parsed
 * Fixed the broken (non-rendering) ReST formatting
 * Added a unit test section, referencing the new README.rst file in nova/testing'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2011-12-05 22:04:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2011-12-06 11:53:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Duncan, apologies for the nitpick but could you run:

First steps towards consolidating testing infrastructure

This commit begins to implement blueprint consolidate-testing-infrastructure by
adding a 'testing' subpackage and moving some modules into it.

commit_message:
Rename .glance-venv to .venv.

This simplifies a number of Jenkins jobs which currently, other
than directory names, could be the same for all OpenStack
projects.  By renaming the virtualenv directory, the redundant
Jenkins virtualenv build and copy jobs can be eliminated.

Change-Id: I7916783d863e5184bad8293c3aed5ba119e374a9

subject: Destroying deleted instances that are running.
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 475, 'name': 'Rick Harris', 'email': 'rick.harris@rackspace.com', 'username': 'rconradharris'}, {'_account_id': 518, 'name': 'Soren Hansen', 'email': 'soren@linux2go.dk', 'username': 'soren'}, {'_account_id': 679, 'name': 'Kevin L. Mitchell', 'email': 'klmitch@mit.edu', 'username': 'klmitch'}, {'_account_id': 1030, 'name': 'Chris Behrens', 'email': 'cbehrens@codestud.com', 'username': 'cbehrens'}, {'_account_id': 1501, 'name': 'Phil Day', 'email': 'philip.day@hp.com', 'username': 'philip-day'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2011-11-19 03:48:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Do not submit

(4 inline comments)

-2 because there's an obvious bug.. commented inline.  And other questions inline.

So, I love the decorators.  I also like the metaclass, but I suspect some others might not like it because you should be able to achieve the same thing by doing a 'dir' on the manager object, looking for '_periodic_task' on the objects.  Although... that gets nasty itself when you want inherited methods to run.  So, I think the metaclass is a little more clean and it's more efficient to only do the scan once.

Keep in mind, I only looked at this very briefly to give you some initial feedback, as I'm just heading out the door. :)"}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2011-11-19 05:22:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (3 inline comments)

Thanks for the quick review!

Comments inline. I'll push up the bug-fix ASAP (good eyes, btw)."}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2011-11-19 15:55:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (2 inline comments)

no prob. :)   Replied.'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2011-11-19 17:11:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2011-11-21 18:46:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

(1 inline comment)

I like the use of a decorator for marking periodic tasks.  I had one DRY-related comment, but this looks good.'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2011-11-22 20:35:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(1 inline comment)

1 thing inline that I think is an issue.

Just some other side comments:  It might be nice to make periodic tasks even more fancy at some point and:
1) Get rid of the periodic_interval flag.
2) In Service.start(), instead of having a timed looping call that calls manager.periodic_tasks(), we could have the decorator specify # of seconds vs # of ticks...  and Service could call each manager's periodic task at the correct time.  Have a greenthread do this that just sleeps until it's time to wake up and call the next periodic task method.

That eliminates the checks on "is it the right time yet?" in the periodic task methods themselves.  And it solves the '# of ticks' issue where '# of ticks' is really arbitrary based on how periodic_interval can change.  And I guess it solves where periodic_interval could be configured with a higher # of seconds than desired by a periodic task.

Dunno if I explained that well...  but this can be done as a next evolution of periodic tasks... not now. :)'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2011-11-23 18:55:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(2 inline comments)

I really like the refactoring of the periodic tasks - very elegant.

I have a couple of comments that aren't blockers - more requests for a rechecked to make sure the change is intended.  

But I would strongly urge that all of this refactoring is split outr and submitted as a seperate blueprint that this bug depends on.  Rolling changes like this together makes it much harder to spot what has changed when from the fix list, and makes it harder to pull out items which we want to backport to Diablo.stable"}, {'account_id': 518, 'date': '2011-12-01 10:49:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(2 inline comments)

Just a couple of nits."}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2011-12-01 16:51:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Great comments all, will work on fixing up this patch today.'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2011-12-02 21:38:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (5 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2011-12-07 08:02:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Abandoned

Abandoning this patch in favor of the following strategy:

1. Move periodic_task decorator refactoring out into a separate patch.

2. Fix context's read_deleted at field in a separate patch (bug #900564)

3. Add the read deleted instances periodic task in a new branch that is dependent upon branches from 1) and 2)."}]

    2. Added support for tasks being scheduled at differing rates via the

    2. Added support for tasks being scheduled at differing rates via the

    3. Fixed `reclaim_queued_deletes so that it doesn't run if

commit_message:
Destroying deleted instances that are running.

Fixes bug #891713

Additional work:

    1. Refactored periodic tasks so that they are registered via a decorator.

    2. Added support for tasks being scheduled at differing rates via the
    `ticks_between_runs` argument.

    3. Fixed `reclaim_queued_deletes so that it doesn't run if
    `FLAGS.reclaim_instance_interval` is 0.

Change-Id: I241a9d7ce078322ac16b1efd5a83b7427adfeea4

commit_message:
vm_state:=error on driver exceptions during resize

Set vm_state to error if a driver raises an exception (of any type)
during resize_instance and finish_resize.

I want to highlight that there is a slight behavioral change here.
Before, on a MigrationError the exception was not reraised in the
resize_instance function. However, based on my understanding it is not
a big deal to make this change. The worst case is log duplication in
a fairly rare error state.

Change-Id: Ifd1ea66cf3f2e59ee06714f666e357a99936b4e3

commit_message:
Changes the namespace from storm to tempest, as well as adding addition tests and improvements
* Changed namespace from storm to tempest
* Added absolute limits service and server personality file tests
* Optimized run time for image metadata tests
* Added additional assertions for create server and rebuild server tests
* Removed any SSH verification until further decisions are made

Change-Id: I5bebd29be382c9404914c7314302670ae09627fc

commit_message:
Rename .melange-venv to .venv.

This simplifies a number of Jenkins jobs which currently, other
than directory names, could be the same for all OpenStack
projects.  By renaming the virtualenv directory, the redundant
Jenkins virtualenv build and copy jobs can be eliminated.

Change-Id: Ib2acff3dd078f3f13a16172f9068cd2b0620d55f

commit_message:
Remove some remnants of ChangeLog and vcsversion.py generation

Since moving to bzr, we no longer generate ChangeLog and vcsversion.py
and since commit deb31cb55 we no longer even have the bzr specific code
for generating them. So, let's just remove any references to them.

Change-Id: I4f96b9be48e289f9129ae8e3ad4cbc1b22db07d2

commit_message:
Use system M2Crypto package on Oneiric, bug 892271

Ubuntu Oneiric has a problem with the pip installed version of m2crypto.
This fix installs python-m2crypto via apt-get on Oneiric.

Change-Id: I8290a74b614eb0d0b8d620dbad19d2cc6843de8b

commit_message:
Fixes LP Bug#862664 - Improper calls to get_image

The glance.client.Client.get_image() call returns a
tuple of (metadata, image_iterator). Unfortunately,
Horizon's glance API calls get_image() when it means
to call get_image_meta(). Because the call to get_image()
simply ignores the image iterator returned from get_image(),
when the image iterator is garbage-collected, this causes
the connection to Glance to be closed, however by that time
the socket bound to the iterator has been switched out by
eventlet. The result is lots of these in the Glance API log:

2011-09-28 17:46:12 DEBUG [glance.store.filesystem] Found image at /opt/stack/glance/images/3. Returning in ChunkedFile.
2011-09-28 17:46:12 DEBUG [eventlet.wsgi.server] Traceback (most recent call last):
    File "/usr/lib/pymodules/python2.7/eventlet/wsgi.py", line 351, in handle_one_response
        write(''.join(towrite))
      File "/usr/lib/pymodules/python2.7/eventlet/wsgi.py", line 301, in write
        _writelines(towrite)
      File "/usr/lib/python2.7/socket.py", line 334, in writelines
        self.flush()
      File "/usr/lib/python2.7/socket.py", line 303, in flush
        self._sock.sendall(view[write_offset:write_offset+buffer_size])
      File "/usr/lib/pymodules/python2.7/eventlet/greenio.py", line 283, in sendall
        tail = self.send(data, flags)
      File "/usr/lib/pymodules/python2.7/eventlet/greenio.py", line 269, in send
        total_sent += fd.send(data[total_sent:], flags)
    error: [Errno 104] Connection reset by peer

This patch fixes the improper calls to get_image() by replacing them
with appropriate calls to get_image_meta().

Change-Id: I741a207ba0e222820492aeb48bab9464d17539ab

revisions:
[{'created': '2011-12-05 16:09:35.000000000', 'message': 'Secondary iteration of fix for bug 891738

A problem exists that images larger than large_object_size without an a priori
image_size will not be segmented and fail to be added to swift.

This patch alters the chunking process slightly:

- Instead of reading min(large_object_chunk_size, bytes_left) from the
  stream, simply read large_object_chunk_size until we reach EOL(None).
  This works even when there is less than large_object_chunk_size bytes
  amount available.

- The image_size can be determined from the combined length of each chunk
  read. If we are passed an unknown image_size this value can be used for
  the registry.

The third argument(image_length) to test_add_already_existing also needed
changing:

Passing a size of 0 now makes the image pass through the segment code path.
This is fine, there is still only one chunk, however, it is called
2.00001 in swift rather than 2. Hence it would not raise a Duplicate
exception.

Change-Id: Ic8b78be5dce2281c80372ed446499f6d0bc07f40
'}, {'created': '2011-12-06 17:56:15.000000000', 'message': 'Secondary iteration of fix for bug 891738

A problem exists that images larger than large_object_size without a
known image_size will fail to be segmented and hence fail to be added
to swift.

This patch alters the chunking process slightly:

- Instead of reading min(large_object_chunk_size, bytes_left) from the
  stream, simply read large_object_chunk_size until we reach EOL(None).
  This works even when there is less than large_object_chunk_size bytes
  amount available.

- The image_size can be determined from the combined length of each
  chunk read. If we are passed an unknown image_size this value can be
  used for the registry.

Test Changes:

- Fixed bug in fake_put_object which was highlighted by Jay when
  reviewing this changeset.
  The put of the manifest object needed to be moved inside the
  check for previous existence of a key.

- Added test_add_large_object_zero_size to
  glance.tests.unit.test_swift_store:TestStore.

  This unit test demonstrates the bug and will test for regressions. It
  mirrors test_add_large_object but specifies an image_size of 0 to
  excercise the new code path.

Change-Id: Ic8b78be5dce2281c80372ed446499f6d0bc07f40
'}]
commit_message:
Secondary iteration of fix for bug 891738

A problem exists that images larger than large_object_size without a
known image_size will fail to be segmented and hence fail to be added
to swift.

This patch alters the chunking process slightly:

- Instead of reading min(large_object_chunk_size, bytes_left) from the
  stream, simply read large_object_chunk_size until we reach EOL(None).
  This works even when there is less than large_object_chunk_size bytes
  amount available.

- The image_size can be determined from the combined length of each
  chunk read. If we are passed an unknown image_size this value can be
  used for the registry.

Test Changes:

- Fixed bug in fake_put_object which was highlighted by Jay when
  reviewing this changeset.
  The put of the manifest object needed to be moved inside the
  check for previous existence of a key.

- Added test_add_large_object_zero_size to
  glance.tests.unit.test_swift_store:TestStore.

  This unit test demonstrates the bug and will test for regressions. It
  mirrors test_add_large_object but specifies an image_size of 0 to
  excercise the new code path.

Change-Id: Ic8b78be5dce2281c80372ed446499f6d0bc07f40

commit_message:
Fixes LP Bug#899383 - Cleanup config file search

Cleans up a bunch of configuration-related errors
when trying to run tempest out of the box with a
simple call to:

$> nosetests storm

* Raises a sensible error if the config file cannot be found
* Makes it possible to set the config file directory and
  config file name via environment variables
* Removes unnecessary calls to create storm.config.StormConfig()
  and share a configuration object by passing the openstack.Manager's
  config object with the various rest client objects
* Updates the README to show how to make a config file and run
  the tests in tempest

Change-Id: I60e33595b88df596cc9585bcaf18d37ae77d6f2b

commit_message:
Secondary iteration of fix for bug 891738

A problem exists that images larger than large_object_size without a
known image_size will fail to be segmented and hence fail to be added
to swift.

This patch alters the chunking process slightly:

- Instead of reading min(large_object_chunk_size, bytes_left) from the
  stream, simply read large_object_chunk_size until we reach EOL(None).
  This works even when there is less than large_object_chunk_size bytes
  amount available.

- The image_size can be determined from the combined length of each
  chunk read. If we are passed an unknown image_size this value can be
  used for the registry.

Test Changes:

- Fixed bug in fake_put_object which was highlighted by Jay when
  reviewing this changeset.
  The put of the manifest object needed to be moved inside the
  check for previous existence of a key.

- Added test_add_large_object_zero_size to
  glance.tests.unit.test_swift_store:TestStore.

  This unit test demonstrates the bug and will test for regressions. It
  mirrors test_add_large_object but specifies an image_size of 0 to
  excercise the new code path.

Change-Id: Ie3d28e44089e05e182cebad44910cf0ffc20fea5

messages:
[{'account_id': 679, 'date': '2011-12-05 16:15:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Looks good, but I wonder if we should mention that this will override the environment variable and/or the service catalog retrieved from Keystone?  (Might be too much information to summarize easily, though...)'}, {'account_id': 455, 'date': '2011-12-05 17:08:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Kevin, is this new flag orthogonal to keystone, ie --url doesn't mean anything if keystone is being used (ie if OS_AUTH_URL is set) in the same way as I don't think you would use '--host' if you are using keystone. Is my understanding correct on this? If so should we 'catch' these 'mixed up' options? ie if someone specifies --url or --host or --port when keystone is switched on (ie OS_AUTH_URL is specified) should we error out with an explanation?"}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2011-12-05 17:45:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

To be honest, I'm not certain.  I had assumed that --url would allow override of the service catalog, since there is already a way to specify the URL if you're not using Keystone.  Without it, there is no real way to override the service catalog--say, if you're trying to actually hit a testing Glance instance, for instance."}, {'account_id': 112, 'date': '2011-12-05 17:53:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

You use --url if you already have the token and endpoint'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2011-12-05 18:26:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

lgtm'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2011-12-06 16:36:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, approved

commit_message:
Refactor: move initialization code to class

- Each script (keystone, keystone-admin, keystone-auth) had a copy
  of the initialization code that handled options, arguments, and
  starting the paste apps. The code was also duplicated in the
  test SetUp code. This code has now been consolidated in one
  class.
- Created the keystone.Server class that has start/stop
  methods to manage keystone servers. It also handles initializing
  options and arguments.
- This provides one point of entry into keystone where we can
  now start refactoring logging and backend code.

Change-Id: Ie4e2a9aae9578c3657c0459381d1618d30b8ca32

commit_message:
Pass '-r' option to 'collie cluster status'.

The  'collie  cluster  status'  default output  is  more  verbose  since
sheepdog 0.24.  The '-r' (raw)  option has  been added for  less verbose
output but won't be used to ensure compatibility with pre-0.24 sheepdog.

Change-Id: Ie31bdded928772250515e439016fc5c5beb00d83

messages:
[{'account_id': 112, 'date': '2011-12-02 06:19:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Is there a reason not have the pot file in source control?  (asking because I'm not sure how this part works)"}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2011-12-02 08:40:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Yes, this is a pain in the ass especially for us packagers, because upon each build we got a modified file in the repository, since it's currently handled by git AND rebuilt from source each time."}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2011-12-05 19:24:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I accept the need to remove it, but I'd appreciate it if you would also add a line to .gitignore for the file; that should help keep it from coming back."}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2011-12-05 23:01:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

++ on adding to .gitignore'}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2011-12-06 08:57:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2011-12-06 11:28:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Yeah, I think it's reasonable to remove this - no-one is keeping the checked in copy up to date by running 'python setup.py build_i18n' anyway

(I recall that some folks make the argument that leaving the generated pot file in git makes it easier for translators, who supposedly might not have the skills to generate the file. However, if translators are using the one in git, we need to keep it up to date)"}, {'account_id': 1528, 'date': '2011-12-06 11:49:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

If it is a generated file, it would be great to remove it. I have not much information about how it's supposed to work and at the same time some reviewers didn't know if I should commit it once it changes, or leave it out."}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2011-12-06 16:13:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, approved

commit_message:
* Added build_url() utility that returns an endpoint URL based on config parameters
* Updated storm.conf
* Added more properties to Nova config object
* Fixed pep8 and the 'set' typo that came from a vi editor 'set list' fumble

commit_message:
Refactor: get rid of keystone/config.py

- The file was unnecessary and the name was confusing.
- Replaced all uses of config.SERVICE with direct references to the
  IdentityService class (which will probably need to be refactored
  away as well).

Change-Id: Id65c2f231376ed76a631e51d91f17023b98636e9

reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 233, 'name': 'Brad Hall', 'email': 'brad@nicira.com', 'username': 'bgh'}, {'_account_id': 385, 'name': 'Jason Kölker', 'email': 'jason@koelker.net', 'username': 'jason-koelker'}, {'_account_id': 679, 'name': 'Kevin L. Mitchell', 'email': 'klmitch@mit.edu', 'username': 'klmitch'}, {'_account_id': 1030, 'name': 'Chris Behrens', 'email': 'cbehrens@codestud.com', 'username': 'cbehrens'}, {'_account_id': 1247, 'name': 'Mark McLoughlin', 'email': 'markmc@redhat.com', 'username': 'markmc'}, {'_account_id': 1456, 'name': 'Aaron Lee', 'email': 'aaron.lee@rackspace.com', 'username': 'aaron-lee'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 385, 'date': '2011-11-29 15:38:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Just some PEP8 errors with trailing whitespace and the quantum test stub func(s) need to be updated to accept the context arg as well. (since all they do is pass, we could *args, **kwargs them so they'll accept anything handed to them)"}, {'account_id': 233, 'date': '2011-11-29 17:29:57.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 385, 'date': '2011-11-29 17:46:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Is Bueno!'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2011-12-01 06:16:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Tests for the new functionality?'}, {'account_id': 233, 'date': '2011-12-01 20:33:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

The very general test_quantum.py tests cover that the new changes don't break anything but don't test whether they actually do what they're supposed to do.  :) I realize we're lacking in code coverage of the QuantumManager so I was going to go through a coverage report and start hammering out tests in the neglected areas as a separate patch set."}, {'account_id': 1456, 'date': '2011-12-02 17:35:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Looks good to me. Instead of code coverage, we might want to list out all of the endpoints, and use that to ensure that everything is covered. I would hate to see dead code tested, just because it's there :) As I see it we could start with a first draft of the message structures headed into QuantumManager https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/formalized-message-structures"}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2011-12-05 19:30:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Looks good to me.  I do wish we had more specific tests here, but I approve of your plan to submit a separate patch with tests for the currently uncovered operations.  (I'm also with Aaron about not wanting to test dead code just because it's there, but... :)"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2011-12-06 12:17:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, approved

Nice!'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2011-12-06 12:25:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-unittests/166/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-merge/561/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-pep8/1936/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2011-12-06 12:25:59.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}]

subject: Removing obsolete bzr-related clauses in setup.py
messages:
[{'account_id': 693, 'date': '2011-11-28 23:35:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

What no test?'}, {'account_id': 321, 'date': '2011-11-29 02:51:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Yay for de-crufting.'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2011-11-29 07:12:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I know this is just removing cruft that can never run now, but I'd like to see the other related code removed too

The main thing that needs fixing is anything vcsversion related in nova/version.py - this should all either be removed leaving just:

  def vcs_version_string():
      return 'LOCALBRANCH:LOCALREVISION'

or go the whole hog and make setup.py write a git commit hash into vcsversion.py and use that

vcsversion.py is also mentioned in run_tests.sh

ChangeLog is mentioned in MANIFEST.in

Remove vcsversion.py and ChangeLog from .bzrignore (maybe .bzrignore is still useful for people using bzr-git?)"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2011-12-06 11:59:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, approved

I'll fix these last bits myself after this is merged"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2011-12-06 12:07:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified

subject: Adding an install_requires to the setup call. Now you can pip install nova on a naked machine.
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 321, 'name': 'Lorin Hochstein', 'email': 'lorinh@gmail.com', 'username': 'lorinh'}, {'_account_id': 475, 'name': 'Rick Harris', 'email': 'rick.harris@rackspace.com', 'username': 'rconradharris'}, {'_account_id': 679, 'name': 'Kevin L. Mitchell', 'email': 'klmitch@mit.edu', 'username': 'klmitch'}, {'_account_id': 693, 'name': 'Christopher MacGown', 'email': 'chris@pistoncloud.com', 'username': '0x44'}, {'_account_id': 1247, 'name': 'Mark McLoughlin', 'email': 'markmc@redhat.com', 'username': 'markmc'}, {'_account_id': 1801, 'name': 'Duncan McGreggor', 'email': 'duncan.mcgreggor@rackspace.com', 'username': 'oubiwann'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 693, 'date': '2011-11-28 23:36:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 321, 'date': '2011-11-29 02:57:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'm not certain this approach will work, as there are some packages that are installed manually by tools/install_venv.py (pip, distribute, greenlet, M2Crypto). 

(greenlet's in the tools/pip_requires, but according to the comments in install_venv.py, it has to be installed manually to get it installed in the right order)."}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2011-11-29 07:40:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'm not sure everything in pip-requires is really appropriate for install_requires - e.g. there's a bunch of stuff just needed by the unit tests, not at runtime

I guess it's better than having no requires listed, though?"}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2011-12-05 18:58:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Yeah, we could stand to split all the various -requires lists a bit more intelligently...'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2011-12-05 20:06:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Nice!'}, {'account_id': 1801, 'date': '2011-12-05 23:33:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

I agree with Lorin and Mark on this one, but this is certainly a good first step. 

What do you think about creating an LP blueprint that:
 * lists the the change you have made here as a first step
 * provides a work item for identifying the various places dependencies are now tracked
 * unifying these in some appropriate place
 * updating setup.py to utilize this for getting a list of required packages
 * ... more?'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2011-12-06 09:14:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, approved

Ok, I think this is better than what we have now and it can be refined over time

Thanks Ben!'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2011-12-06 09:22:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-unittests/161/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-merge/556/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-pep8/1931/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2011-12-06 12:07:34.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}]

subject: Make admin_password keyword in compute manager run_instance method match what we send in the compute API. Fixes bug #900591.
messages:
[{'account_id': 112, 'date': '2011-12-06 05:24:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2011-12-06 11:41:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, approved

Nice catch Dan!

Looks like a recently introduced regression caused by 0d54770:

  -    def _run_instance(self, context, instance_uuid, **kwargs):
  +    def _run_instance(self, context, instance_uuid,
  +                      requested_networks=None,
  +                      injected_files=[],
  +                      admin_pass=None,
  +                      **kwargs):

  -        instance['admin_pass'] = kwargs.get('admin_password', None)"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2011-12-06 11:49:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified

commit_message:
Make admin_password keyword in compute manager run_instance method match
what we send in the compute API. Fixes bug #900591.

Change-Id: I857b7787189d454e8ed17a43654d6bf944da003e

commit_message:
Fixes a typo preventing attaching RBD volumes.

A typo in spelling 'rbd' as 'rdb' prevents attaching RBD volumes
to instances.

Fixes bug 900359.

Change-Id: I872369a21b5935c37c4299f3f748d2d133a78bb3

subject: support gerrit style refs/changes/... for branch names
messages:
[{'account_id': 112, 'date': '2011-12-05 21:44:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 112, 'date': '2011-12-05 22:57:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 112, 'date': '2011-12-05 23:07:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 1, 'date': '2011-12-05 23:34:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

This will leave the git tree in detached head state, which is probably fine -- depends on whether the next thing you expect to do with the tree is throw it away, or commit a change.  

However, if the use case for this is to test out a change, and possibly update it, then it may be worth having devstack simulate exactly what git-review would do in this case, including checking out onto a specially named branch, such that a subsequent git-review is run, it is uploaded with the same topic.

One way to implement this would be to use git-review.  Perhaps the following modification to this change:

If 'git-review' is in the path, use "git review -d CHANGEID" instead of the checkout/fetch, if not, leave the code as-is.

I'm not sure whether this is a use case you're targeting, and whether you would expect SSH keys, etc, to be available for git-review in the target environment.'}, {'account_id': 112, 'date': '2011-12-05 23:36:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

James,

Good point.  Right now this is mostly for bots (jenkins) but using git-review would be more "dev" centered'}, {'account_id': 1, 'date': '2011-12-05 23:54:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

For the CI jenkins, I took the approach of setting up the repos outside of devstack.  There's a small win in caching if you can avoid re-cloning them and instead just configure them appropriately and copy them over to the devstack environment.

https://github.com/openstack/openstack-ci/blob/master/slave_scripts/devstack-vm-gate.sh"}, {'account_id': 1155, 'date': '2011-12-06 06:16:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, approved

lgtm'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2011-12-06 06:17:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-devstack-merge/21/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2011-12-06 06:17:01.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}]

[{'created': '2011-12-05 21:38:34.000000000', 'message': 'support gerrit style refs/changes/... for branch names

Change-Id: I0793415fb03cc08d1eb1a3faf1b8ec3e723beb31
'}, {'created': '2011-12-05 21:44:08.000000000', 'message': 'support gerrit style refs/changes/... for branch names

Change-Id: I0793415fb03cc08d1eb1a3faf1b8ec3e723beb31

Change-Id: I0793415fb03cc08d1eb1a3faf1b8ec3e723beb31
'}, {'created': '2011-12-05 23:07:47.000000000', 'message': 'support gerrit style refs/changes/... for branch names

To use a gerrit "branch" with devstack I would find the repo/remote and
set it for the specific project.

Example: https://review.openstack.org/2059

Would mean I update my localrc with the following settings:

KEYSTONE_REPO=https://review.openstack.org/p/openstack/keystone
KEYSTONE_BRANCH=refs/changes/59/2059/2

Change-Id: I0793415fb03cc08d1eb1a3faf1b8ec3e723beb31
'}]
commit_message:
support gerrit style refs/changes/... for branch names

To use a gerrit "branch" with devstack I would find the repo/remote and
set it for the specific project.

Example: https://review.openstack.org/2059

Would mean I update my localrc with the following settings:

KEYSTONE_REPO=https://review.openstack.org/p/openstack/keystone
KEYSTONE_BRANCH=refs/changes/59/2059/2

Change-Id: I0793415fb03cc08d1eb1a3faf1b8ec3e723beb31

commit_message:
Rename .keystone-venv to .venv.

This simplifies a number of Jenkins jobs which currently, other
than directory names, could be the same for all OpenStack
projects.  By renaming the virtualenv directory, the redundant
Jenkins virtualenv build and copy jobs can be eliminated.

Change-Id: Ia831674b6e9c9d2be25b54e26c92009778d97a22

[{'created': '2011-12-06 01:37:13.000000000', 'message': "Fixes missed tests and subsequently introduced bugs

- bug 900514 fixed: some test files were marked as
  executable. Nose by default skips those. They've
  been reset to 644.
- bug 900525 was introduced in the refactoring of
  the backend code. The test was not impacted but
  the load fixture code was. This has been addressed
  and the test passes again. No nchanges needed to
  the code being tested (i.e. no bugs introduced)

Change-Id: I87ee799a47f90c383e181d203fd783c77fa4b3e5
"}]
commit_message:
Fixes missed tests and subsequently introduced bugs

- bug 900514 fixed: some test files were marked as
  executable. Nose by default skips those. They've
  been reset to 644.
- bug 900525 was introduced in the refactoring of
  the backend code. The test was not impacted but
  the load fixture code was. This has been addressed
  and the test passes again. No nchanges needed to
  the code being tested (i.e. no bugs introduced)

Change-Id: I87ee799a47f90c383e181d203fd783c77fa4b3e5

commit_message:
Converts keypairs to use the new ajax modal dialogs.

Incidentally updates jQuery to 1.7.1 and uses the "on" method instead of "live"
for click handling as per Tres' comment.

Adds a common "main_content" id to all the base.html templates for uniformity.

Change-Id: I667cfaa72b9b85883a86649a666e75e4d501b93e

commit_message:
Add availabity_zone to the refresh list

The availability_zone column for a service record is not updated if the
availability_zone is changed after the record was created.  This patch
adds availability_zone to the update list in report_state if the
availability_zone stored in the database does not match the local flag

Change-Id: I869384af113517adfba3a675f757e51687b3c15e

commit_message:
Implement resize down for XenAPI

This patch implements resizing an instance to a smaller disk. It implements
this by copying the VDI and running e2resize, before transferring to the
new host.

Change-Id: Ic901a59cb6cdb79605c70528cf85064d8335ee2f

commit_message:
Bug #896997: nova-vncproxy's flash socket policy port is not configurable

Add flags called vncproxy_flash_socket_policy_port and
vncproxy_flash_socket_policy_host, to allow the admin to configure
the Flash socket policy listener.

Change-Id: If42839ccd86f1c8723221049d7c76b6f5ad0aa2d

revisions:
[{'created': '2011-11-30 18:55:46.000000000', 'message': "Bug #898290: iSCSI volume backend treats FLAGS.host as a hostname

Change ISCSIDriver to set volume.provider_location during create_export.
This records the location of the LUN, so that nova-compute does not need
to run the iSCSI discovery code itself.

As part of this, include the IP address of the target in the provider_location.
This IP address is carefully selected to be the one on the correct network,
i.e. matching --iscsi_ip_prefix.  This means that we don't use volume's
host identifier (which could be an opaque ID) when trying to connect to the
iSCSI target -- we use the correct IP address instead.

The string-join to set provider_location is shared with ZadaraBEDriver,
which was doing something similar.  I've brought that into a helper function.

This change includes whataremyips(), taken from swift.common.utils.
This adds a dependency on netifaces.

The docstring for the --host flag has been clarified.
Change-Id: I8402da86345e786a46a4d222ad4d8a4449d2bd3f
"}, {'created': '2011-11-30 19:10:13.000000000', 'message': "Bug #898290: iSCSI volume backend treats FLAGS.host as a hostname
